fields.name: main_wikipage
fields.text:
# API Wiki main page

## Purpose

The API wiki serves to collect practical information about things at the API, whether technical, administrative, social or otherwise. You can put things like FAQs here, or have a progress page on the latests happenings regarding e.g. an upcoming or current event. 

These wiki pages are editable only by API people, but accessible, and thus readable, by all API people. Information about, for example, a research group, that is sensitive shouldn't be on this wiki.

## Content

You can find the list of all pages [here](/internal/wiki/all/)  
Students or employees that are new to the institute and/or linux might want to start with the [tips for newcomers](for_newcomers).

## Creating a new page

Use the ["create a new page"](/internal/wiki/create/) link on the left. A page name can consist of numbers and letters, underscores and dashes; the difference between upper- and lowercase is ignored. There is no explicit wiki naming necessity or convention like CapitalizedWords.

You can create or use existing *category* pages to groups things and keep a set of pages together.

## Edit a page

Click on the blue "Edit page" link to edit a page. The editing box appears below the preview box on the actual editing page; the preview gets updated once you've pressed "Save".

This wiki uses markdown with a few extensions (for eg tables) for layout. See the ["help on editing"](help-editing-wikipage) page for more information.

## Page history

There is *no* page history or undo function. If you remove text and then save the edited page, or delete a page, you cannot undo that. You can always make a copy of the old text in a simple text file, to be on the safe side.

API Wiki main page

Purpose

The API wiki serves to collect practical information about things at the API, whether technical, administrative, social or otherwise. You can put things like FAQs here, or have a progress page on the latests happenings regarding e.g. an upcoming or current event.

These wiki pages are editable only by API people, but accessible, and thus readable, by all API people. Information about, for example, a research group, that is sensitive shouldn't be on this wiki.

Content

You can find the list of all pages here
Students or employees that are new to the institute and/or linux might want to start with the tips for newcomers.

Creating a new page

Use the "create a new page" link on the left. A page name can consist of numbers and letters, underscores and dashes; the difference between upper- and lowercase is ignored. There is no explicit wiki naming necessity or convention like CapitalizedWords.

You can create or use existing category pages to groups things and keep a set of pages together.

Edit a page

Click on the blue "Edit page" link to edit a page. The editing box appears below the preview box on the actual editing page; the preview gets updated once you've pressed "Save".

This wiki uses markdown with a few extensions (for eg tables) for layout. See the "help on editing" page for more information.

Page history

There is no page history or undo function. If you remove text and then save the edited page, or delete a page, you cannot undo that. You can always make a copy of the old text in a simple text file, to be on the safe side.

fields.name: help-editing-wikipage
fields.text:
# How to edit a wikipage

This wiki uses markdown to mark-up the layout of the wiki pages. There is a [full description](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) of the markdown syntax, but below are examples of the nost common uses.

In contrast to the actual markdown specificiation, HTML tags cannot be used on this wiki. Also, a few extra options are available, for creating [definition lists](http://www.freewisdom.org/projects/python-markdown/Definition_Lists), [footnotes](http://www.freewisdom.org/projects/python-markdown/Footnotes) or [simple tables](http://www.freewisdom.org/projects/python-markdown/Tables).

Use the source of this page for an idea how to use the markup syntax.

## Basic markdown

Use \**single*\* or \*\***double**\*\* asterisks for emphasis. Special characters like an \*, \_ or a \\ can be escaped by prepending it with a \\.

Paragraphs are automatically created when text is separated by an empty line. Paragraphs are preferred over line breaks, which can be forced by adding two spaces at the end of the line.

For (sub)section titles , use \# in front of the section title: 

    # section level 1 (page title)  
    ## section level 2  
    ### section level 3

etc, results in:

# section level 1 (page title)  
## section level 2  
### section level 3

Note that the section levels layout follows the default layout of the API webpages.
You can also underline titles with dashes or equal signs.


    * Lists are easily made
    * Do not put blank lines between list items
    * You can also use a \+ or \- sign,  
      and have text across multiple lines

which results in:

* Lists are easily made
* Do not put blank lines between list items
* You can also use a \+ or \- sign,  
  and have text across multiple lines

> You can create quotes using \>; the quotes  
> can of course span more lines

Text indented by four spaces (or tab) forms a code block.

Three or more dashes in a paragraph on their own form a horizontal line.

---

## Links

A simple link can be created \[as this\]\(wiki\), which would be a relative link to a page called "wiki", but with the text "as this". This would be a link on the wiki site itself; for outside links, use the full URL (including the http).

For some links, you may prefer to separate them from the main text, using a *label*, \[as in this example\]\[some label\]. The label is then later used to specify the actual link, as below. And this can even be \[shorter\]\[\] using an empty label.

\[some label\]: http://www.astro.uva.nl/internal/

\[shorter\]: http://www.astro.uva.nl/institute/

## Images

Unfortunately, you can't upload images to this wiki, but you can put them elsewhere and then link from here. The syntax is similar to the one for URLs, but starting with an \!\[exclamation mark\]\(http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1149/1070601182_0fe532a667.jpg\)]![exclamation mark](http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1149/1070601182_0fe532a667_s.jpg). You can use the label technique as for URLs.

## Tables

You can only create very simple tables, but for the purposes of this wiki, that is hopefully sufficient. An example table:

    First Header  | Second Header
    ------------- | -------------
    Content Cell  | Content Cell
    Content Cell  | Content Cell

looks like


First Header  | Second Header
------------- | -------------
Content Cell  | Content Cell
Content Cell  | Content Cell

fields.name: login-information-linux
fields.text:
# Computing Environment at API

The purpose of this page is to give you an overview and reference
of the hardware and software available at the astronomical institute
Anton Pannekoek (focussed on the cluster of LINUX workstations).

### Logging in on UNIX

When you login on a UNIX workstation the following scripts are executed:

* \~/.cshrc     [(example)](cshrc) 
* \~/.pkgrc     [(example)](pkgrc)
* \~/.env.csh [(example)](env)
* \~/.aliases  [(example)](aliases)
* \~/.login      [(example)](login)

The symbol \~ is a notation for your home directory.

The .cshrc is started automatically for every shell you run.
It is the very first file executed.
The default .cshrc does the following:

* runs the softpkg program
* read environment variable definitions from .env.csh
* read aliases from .aliases

A .cshrc file is automatically installed in your home directory when your
account is created.  You may modify it,
though most changes can also be implemented by adapting
your .pkgrc, .env.csh and .aliases file.

Please check that this statement is in the .cshrc file:

setenv PACKAGEPATH /home/sw-astro/pkg:/usr/local/pkg

The .pkgrc contains a list of software packages you want to use 
(like eg. gcc, pgplot, psutils).
The softpkg program reads this file and changes you environment variables
so you can use the programs in an easy way.
To see which packages are available type softpkg -l.

The .env.csh is started from the .cshrc. This file is
intented for environment variables that you may want to define.

The .aliases is also started from .cshrc once the
.env.csh has completed execution. The .aliases is
intented for storing aliases for commonly used commands.

Once the aliases are read, the C shell starts the .login script.
You should not modify it.

If you make changes to one of these files, they are only working
if you login again or start a new xterm.

---

### Tips

To help you a bit, you can run the following script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-login

This script replaces the default login files a user gets,
when his/her account was created by the ict-people. 
The old login files are backupped and a new set of files
are installed, which are suitable for our "astro" environment.
Also some iraf settings are already in these new files.

Another script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-iraf

installs a iraf sub-directoy in the user's (your) home directory. 
This directory contains all the necesary files a user needs
for using iraf.
If a user already had an iraf directory, that one will be backupped.

After you run both scripts above please logoff and login again.
fields.html:
Computing Environment at API

The purpose of this page is to give you an overview and reference of the hardware and software available at the astronomical institute Anton Pannekoek (focussed on the cluster of LINUX workstations).

Logging in on UNIX

When you login on a UNIX workstation the following scripts are executed:

  • ~/.cshrc (example)
  • ~/.pkgrc (example)
  • ~/.env.csh (example)
  • ~/.aliases (example)
  • ~/.login (example)

The symbol ~ is a notation for your home directory.

The .cshrc is started automatically for every shell you run. It is the very first file executed. The default .cshrc does the following:

  • runs the softpkg program
  • read environment variable definitions from .env.csh
  • read aliases from .aliases

A .cshrc file is automatically installed in your home directory when your account is created. You may modify it, though most changes can also be implemented by adapting your .pkgrc, .env.csh and .aliases file.

Please check that this statement is in the .cshrc file:

setenv PACKAGEPATH /home/sw-astro/pkg:/usr/local/pkg

The .pkgrc contains a list of software packages you want to use (like eg. gcc, pgplot, psutils). The softpkg program reads this file and changes you environment variables so you can use the programs in an easy way. To see which packages are available type softpkg -l.

The .env.csh is started from the .cshrc. This file is intented for environment variables that you may want to define.

The .aliases is also started from .cshrc once the .env.csh has completed execution. The .aliases is intented for storing aliases for commonly used commands.

Once the aliases are read, the C shell starts the .login script. You should not modify it.

If you make changes to one of these files, they are only working if you login again or start a new xterm.

Tips

To help you a bit, you can run the following script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-login

This script replaces the default login files a user gets, when his/her account was created by the ict-people. The old login files are backupped and a new set of files are installed, which are suitable for our "astro" environment. Also some iraf settings are already in these new files.

Another script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-iraf

installs a iraf sub-directoy in the user's (your) home directory. This directory contains all the necesary files a user needs for using iraf. If a user already had an iraf directory, that one will be backupped.

After you run both scripts above please logoff and login again.

#  
    #       .env.csh  
    #  
    #       this file is sourced by the standard .cshrc file  
    #  

    # 
    # set default printer to your satisfaction  
    #  
    setenv PRINTER                      p005204  
    setenv LPDEST                        p005204  
    setenv MOZ_PRINTER_NAME p005204  

    if ( ! "$?LINES" )         setenv LINES  
    if ( ! "$?COLUMNS" )  setenv COLUMNS  

    # Iraf  
    setenv SAOTNG_FIFO  /home/${USER}/iraf/dev/imt1

fields.name: pkgrc
fields.text:
#  
    #    Default packages loaded by softpkg  
    #  
    #    .pkgrc  
    #  

    #    The DEFAULT package may differ across architectures, it contains  
    #    at least local utilities. It also includes the search-path components  
    #  
    #    \~/bin/sh or $HOME/bin/sh for your own shell scripts, and  
    #    \~/bin/ARCH or $HOME/ARCH  where ARCH is sparc for suns,  
    #    RS6000 for ibms, i386 for unix-pc's.  
    #    Store your own binary executables here.  
    #    softpkg -D show your systems architecture.  

    # DEFAULT  

    #    uncomment the next entry to have "." ($cwd) in your path  

    # dot  

    #    If a package starts with a slash (\/) or a percent (\%) it is not  
    #    considered a package name but an absolute path of a directory.  
    #    Softpkg will check for its existence, and if it exists include  
    #    the absolute path in the definition of the PATH variable.  

    #    So if you want to include a bin directory in a project directory which  
    #    is in your home directory, you can include something like:  

    # %HOME/project/bin  

    #    WARNING  
    #  
    #    If, for example, you want to use the Java Development kit, DO NOT   
    #    include /usr/local/java as an absolute path in your .pkgrc file.  
    #    Instead DO use the predefined package "java".  
    #  
    #    softpkg -l  
    #  
    #    shows all packages that are installed.  
    #    In general, preinstalled  package names are preferred.  
    #  
    #    Note in the above example that %XXX are softpkg variables.  
    #    Softpkg will not expand $YYY shell variables.  
    #    You may use the following softpkg variables:  
    #  
    #    %USER          your username  
    #    %HOME         your home directory. typically /home/%USER  
    #    %ARCH          the systems processor architecture  
    #    %HOST          the systems hostname  
    #    %OSNAME     the name of the operating system in lowercase  
    #    %OSMAJOR   the major operating system revision  
    #    %OSMINOR    the minor operating system revision  
    #  

    #    Add your own packages below  
    user  
    gnu  
    sm  
    nedit  
    iraf  
    funtools  
    utilities  
    sys  
    dot  
    DEFAULT

fields.name: aliases
fields.text:
#
    #   Aliases file sourced in the .cshrc file
    #
    #   .aliases
    #

    alias   h  'history 23'
    alias   l  'ls -F'
    alias   ll 'ls -lFt'
    alias   la 'ls -alFt'
    alias   .  'source'
    alias   j  'jobs -l'
    alias   z  'suspend'

    alias cwdcmd 'set prompt="${HOST}:${PWD}> "'
    alias up     'cd ..'
    alias lo     'logout'
    alias dir    'll'
    alias env    'env | sort'

    # Iraf aliases
    alias start_iraf 'source /home/sw-astro/iraf/iraf/unix/hlib/irafuser.csh'
    alias ds9         "/home/sw-astro/utilities/bin/ds9  -fifo  /home/${USER}/iraf/dev/imt1 &"
fields.html:

fields.name: cshrc
fields.text:
#
    #      .cshrc file
    #

    umask 022

    # softpkg sets the PATH, MANPATH and LPATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables.
    # see man softpkg

    if ( -x /usr/local/bin/softpkg ) then
        setenv PACKAGEPATH /home/sw-astro/pkg:/usr/local/pkg
        eval `/usr/local/bin/softpkg`
    else
        set path = (/bin /usr/local/bin)
        set nosoftpkg
    endif

    # read additional environment variables from ~/.env.csh

    if ( -r ${HOME}/.env.csh ) source ${HOME}/.env.csh

    # read aliases from ~/.aliases

    if ( -r ${HOME}/.aliases ) source ${HOME}/.aliases

    if ( $?prompt ) then
        set cdpath = ( ${HOME} ${HOME}/src )
        set history = 40
        set filec
        set nobeep
        set notify
        if ( $?tcsh ) then
            set prompt = "(${USER}@%M %h) "
        else
            set prompt = "(${USER}@${HOST} \!) "
        endif

        set history=50                # previous commands to remember.
        set savehist=50             # number to save across sessions.
        umask 022                      # set umask to 022
        unlimit descriptors
        limit stacksize unlimited
        unset autologout
        set autolist=ambiguous
        set prompt="${LOGNAME}@${HOST}:${PWD}> "

        if ("$?DISPLAY") then
           if ( -r ${HOME}/.Xdefaults ) xrdb -merge ${HOME}/.Xdefaults
        endif

    endif
fields.html:
#
#      .cshrc file
#

umask 022

# softpkg sets the PATH, MANPATH and LPATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables.
# see man softpkg

if ( -x /usr/local/bin/softpkg ) then
    setenv PACKAGEPATH /home/sw-astro/pkg:/usr/local/pkg
    eval `/usr/local/bin/softpkg`
else
    set path = (/bin /usr/local/bin)
    set nosoftpkg
endif

# read additional environment variables from ~/.env.csh

if ( -r ${HOME}/.env.csh ) source ${HOME}/.env.csh

# read aliases from ~/.aliases

if ( -r ${HOME}/.aliases ) source ${HOME}/.aliases

if ( $?prompt ) then
    set cdpath = ( ${HOME} ${HOME}/src )
    set history = 40
    set filec
    set nobeep
    set notify
    if ( $?tcsh ) then
        set prompt = "(${USER}@%M %h) "
    else
        set prompt = "(${USER}@${HOST} \!) "
    endif

    set history=50                # previous commands to remember.
    set savehist=50             # number to save across sessions.
    umask 022                      # set umask to 022
    unlimit descriptors
    limit stacksize unlimited
    unset autologout
    set autolist=ambiguous
    set prompt="${LOGNAME}@${HOST}:${PWD}> "

    if ("$?DISPLAY") then
       if ( -r ${HOME}/.Xdefaults ) xrdb -merge ${HOME}/.Xdefaults
    endif

endif

fields.name: administration
fields.text:
# Administration

## Contact information:
* [Phone numbers and email adresses for UvA  departments](contactinformation)

## Overview of API email lists
* institute@list.uva.nl (everybody at the API)
* api-staff@list.uva.nl (staff at the API)
* api-supervisors@list.uva.nl (people supervising students at API)
* api-lecturers@list.uva.nl (people teaching at API)
* phd-astro@list.uva.nl (all phd students at API)
* msc-astro@list.uva.nl (all masterstudents at API)
* api-colloq@list.uva.nl (mailinglist for colloquia held at the API)

## Required paperwork for PhD or Master
### PhD
* [All you need to know for your PhD graduation](phd_graduation)
### Master
* [PEP form](http://student.uva.nl/astro/az/content/study-programme/pep/pep.html) 
* [Research training contract](http://student.uva.nl/astro/az/content/study-programme/research-project/research-project.html)

fields.name: remote-access
fields.text:
# Remote access

### How do I log in to another computer in the network?

To access another computer in the institute, use:

    > ssh computername

where computername is the name (f.e. `astro001`) or number (f.e. `u013469`) of the computer. (If you want to use more than just the terminal, add ' -Y' to enable X11 forwarding. If you login from another account, use `ssh username@computername`)

### How do I get to files on another computer at the institute? 

The `scratch` (and sometimes `scratch1`) partitions of most of the institute's machines can be approached via the `/net` directory; for instance, `/net/astro001/scratch1` is the `/scratch1` partition belonging to `astro001` (students' machine). 


### How do I access my files from a linux computer outside the university?

You can log in via ssh, and/or download files via scp. You cannot access computers at the institute directly, you have to login to the mremote server first:

    > ssh username@mremote.science.uva.nl

(If you want to use more than just the terminal, add ' -Y' to enable X11 forwarding)
From there you can access your home directory and scratch drives mounted in /net , or you can login to another machine in the network using ssh.

* *If X11 forwarding doesn't work:*

If you have trouble opening new windows from the terminal, check that X11 forwarding is allowed.   First, edit the sshd_config file (located in /etc/ or /etc/ssh) to include the following uncommented line,

    > X11Forwarding yes

You will need root access to edit sshd_config.  You will then need to set up an ssh tunnel from your local machine (i.e., the laptop you are using), through mremote into the desktop you are trying to access on the API network.  In this example, the desktop you are accessing has a name like 'u######', and the tunnel is opened through port 4022.

     > ssh -Y -L 4022:u######.science.uva.nl:22  username@remote.science.uva.nl

Now, you can ssh into your desktop by opening a new terminal and typing:

     > ssh -Y -p4022 username@localhost

The -p command tells ssh to use port 4022 that you just opened.  Now you should be able to open new windows from the terminal.


* *To download files from your home account, use*

    > scp username@mremote.science.uva.nl:filename .

* *If you want to copy files from your scratch area, use something like*

    > scp -r username@mremote.science.uva.nl:/net/astro001/scratch/username/subdir/file(s) .

You can also use programs that use sftp or ssh for file transfer, but ftp wil not work.

### How to copy files to a local API machine, if that machine is not visible from mremote

(Whereby "not visible" means you can't browse to it using /net/.)

This can happen for certain machines, or when the /net/ links aren't working for some reason.

One solution is to use an ssh tunnel, with mremote.science.uva.nl as intermediate; very similar to the above section. An example for my account on localhost:

    ssh -L 2222:u028606.1x.uva.nl:22 martin@mremote.science.uva.nl

If ssh asks for your password, this will be your password on mremote.science.uva.nl.
Now port 2222 on the localhost is tied to port 22 (ssh/scp) on u028606, through mremote.science.uva.nl.

Then, in another terminal on the localhost (this should be the machine that has the data), you can use:

    scp -P 2222 datafile[s] martin@localhost:.

meaning that scp uses port 2222 and copies files to localhost. Since port 2222 is tunneled to port 22 on u028606 however, these files are copied over to u028606. If scp asks for your password, this will be your password on u028606.1x.uva.nl.

Of course, "martin" should be your appropriate science account, "u028606" the machine you want to copy stuff to and 2222 can be any port between 1024 and 65536 if wanted.



### How do I access my files from a windows computer outside the university?

You will need a terminal program like [putty](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html) to login to mremote.science.uva.nl. If you want to use X11 forwarding, wou will need an X server such as [Xming](http://www.straightrunning.com/XmingNotes/), [Cygwin+X11](http://x.cygwin.com/) or [vncserver](http://www.tightvnc.com/).

For those who are using vncviewer and putty at home, we'll explain how to setup this ssh tunneling. Here we go:

You start the vncserver on your computer at the api (say mira).  
The default port will be 5901

Then in putty (category) at Session you fill in at Host Name:  
mremote.science.uva.nl port 22

Go to (category) SSH --> Tunnels  
Type in source port: 5901  
Type in destination: mira.science.uva.nl:5901   
Click on Add

Then go to (category)  Session,  
click on Default Settings and click on Save.  
This is for next time you start putty.

Click "Open" at the bottom of putty.  
You will get a xterm to log in to remote.  
Just do that.


And now the Magic!  
Click on vncviewer.  
Fill in at VNC server: 127.0.0.1:1  
Click on connect and there it comes!!!!!!!

fields.name: installing_iraf_on_ubuntu
fields.text:
This is a installation for an Ubuntu 32-bit system.

For 64-bit systems, look at the Ubuntu 64-bit page

This page is taken from: [http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation](http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation)

some extra comments on how to get furhter are added at places were I got stuk installing.

# General Warning

This guide asks you to install several packages plucked from a arbitrary location on the internet, including libc (arbitrary = not a default Ubuntu package repository). These packages also are dated 2007. 

This may therefore render your system (or parts of it; think other software) unusable. Proceed with caution, if at all!

Better may be to just follow the general IRAF installation, as detailed in the IRAF documentation. This doesn't install ds9, X11IRAF or xgterm, but also doesn't require (in general) to download extra packages.


# IRAF Setup on Ubuntu/Debian

This page describes how to setup IRAF on a 32-bit Ubuntu/Debian machine.
Installation of X11IRAF and DS9 are also included, plus installation of Tablfor 32-bit systemes
and STSDAS are shown as an example of adding external packages.

It will be easiest if you just copy-paste the instructions one by one.
Please be sure to read and implement the instructions in [[brackets]] as well.

For 64-bit installation, see -
http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation_64bit

Please send questions or comments to:
khan@astronomy.ohio-state.edu

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

sudo apt-get install tcsh

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/ldso_1.9.11-15_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i ldso_1.9.11-15_i386.deb

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/libc5_5.4.46-15_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i libc5_5.4.46-15_i386.deb

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/termcap-compat_1.2.3_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i termcap-compat_1.2.3_i386.deb

[[Use System>Administration>Users and Groups to create an account with username 
"iraf", real name "IRAF Maintenance", home directory "/iraf/iraf/local", shell 
"/bin/tcsh", and a secure password. Be sure to grant admin privilege to this 
account. For sudo commands here on, use this password. An easy way to avoid 
confusion is to assign the same password to this account as to your other / 
sys-admin account.]]

[The following step didn't work for me and some fellow students. If it doesn't work, try taking away the / infront og iraf, thus sudo chown -R iraf:iraf iraf. Afterwards, take all /'s at the beginning of a path away.]

sudo chown -R iraf:iraf /iraf

su iraf

mkdir /iraf/irafbin

mkdir /iraf/irafbin/bin.linux

mkdir /iraf/irafbin/noao.bin.linux

mkdir /iraf/x11iraf

mkdir /iraf/extern

cd /iraf/iraf

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/as.pcix.gen.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/as.pcix.gen.gz  ]]

tar -zxf as.pcix.gen.gz

rm as.pcix.gen.gz

cd /iraf/iraf/unix/bin.redhat/

mv * ../bin.linux/

cd /iraf/irafbin/bin.linux

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/ib.rhux.x86.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/ib.rhux.x86.gz  ]]

tar -zxpf ib.rhux.x86.gz

rm ib.rhux.x86.gz

cd /iraf/irafbin/noao.bin.linux

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/nb.rhux.x86.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/nb.rhux.x86.gz  ]]

tar -zxpf nb.rhux.x86.gz

rm nb.rhux.x86.gz

[In the following command, my laptop couldn't find setenv. I think it is a typo and is suppose to be: set env iraf irad/iraf/]

setenv iraf /iraf/iraf/

cd $iraf/unix/hlib

source irafuser.csh

[[Choose default paths as will be shown in on-screen prompt parentheses.
Type "y" only where "yes" returns "huh?".]]

sudo ./install

sudo apt-get install libncurses5

cd /iraf/x11iraf/

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/x11iraf/x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/x11iraf/x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]
 
tar -zxf x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz 

[[ Or: tar -zxf x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]

mv lib.redhat lib.linux

mv bin.redhat bin.linux

sudo ./install

rm x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz

[[ Or: rm x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]

wget http://hea-www.harvard.edu/saord/download/ds9/linux/ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz
 
tar -zxf ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz

rm ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz

sudo mv ds9 /usr/local/bin/

exit

cd

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf

sudo chmod u=rwx iraf

mkdir ~/IRAF

cd ~/IRAF

mkiraf

[[Select "xgterm" as your IRAF shell when prompted.]]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The command ./iraf will now launch a complete IRAF session containing DS9,
xgterm and ecl, based in ~/IRAF. Alternately, type "ecl" for enhanced IRAF, "cl"
for regular IRAF, and "ds9" for standalone DS9 launch. 

Repeat the last 5 steps for each user as needed.

The following steps show how to add external packages. This example install 
Tables and STSDAS. If you don't need extra packages, then you are done already.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

su iraf

cd /iraf/extern/

mkdir tables stsdas

cd /iraf/extern/tables/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

python python/compileall.py ./python

python python/compileall.py ./python/*

nano /iraf/iraf/unix/hlib/extern.pkg

[[Now, edit this file so that it look like what follows. Do not delete any 
existing lines, just add the new lines that has "stsdas" or "tables" or 
"apropos" in them.]]

-----------------------------------------

reset noao = iraf$noao/

task noao.pkg = noao$noao.cl

reset tables = /iraf/extern/tables/
task tables.pkg = tables$tables.cl

reset stsdas = /iraf/extern/stsdas/
task stsdas.pkg = stsdas$stsdas.cl
task apropos = stsdas$apropos.cl

reset helpdb = lib$helpdb.mip \
,noao$lib/helpdb.mip \
,tables$lib/helpdb.mip \
,stsdas$lib/helpdb.mip \


keep

-----------------------------------------

[[Use ctrl-x to exit, answer "y" to save file, press enter to confirm.]

exit

cd

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now, tables and stsdas are available for use inside iraf. Some of the other
commonly used packages are ared, mscred, color, ctio, fitsutil, gemini, gmisc,
nmisc, rvsao and xdimsum. Google will help you find the packages and you can set
them up (similar to the example given here for stsdas/tables) following the 
instructions of the host pages.

Repeat the last 5 steps for each user as needed.

The following steps show how to add external packages. This example install Tables and STSDAS. If you don't need extra packages, then you are done already.

su iraf

cd /iraf/extern/

mkdir tables stsdas

cd /iraf/extern/tables/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

python python/compileall.py ./python

python python/compileall.py ./python/*

nano /iraf/iraf/unix/hlib/extern.pkg

[[Now, edit this file so that it look like what follows. Do not delete any existing lines, just add the new lines that has "stsdas" or "tables" or "apropos" in them.]]

reset noao = iraf$noao/

task noao.pkg = noao$noao.cl

reset tables = /iraf/extern/tables/ task tables.pkg = tables$tables.cl

reset stsdas = /iraf/extern/stsdas/ task stsdas.pkg = stsdas$stsdas.cl task apropos = stsdas$apropos.cl

reset helpdb = lib$helpdb.mip ,noao$lib/helpdb.mip ,tables$lib/helpdb.mip ,stsdas$lib/helpdb.mip \

keep

[[Use ctrl-x to exit, answer "y" to save file, press enter to confirm.]

exit

cd

Now, tables and stsdas are available for use inside iraf. Some of the other commonly used packages are ared, mscred, color, ctio, fitsutil, gemini, gmisc, nmisc, rvsao and xdimsum. Google will help you find the packages and you can set them up (similar to the example given here for stsdas/tables) following the instructions of the host pages.

fields.name: installing_iraf_on_ubuntu_64bit
fields.text:
This is a installation for an Ubuntu 64 bit system.

For 32-bit see the other page on installing iraf on ubuntu.

taken from: [http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation_64bit](http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation_64bit)


# General Warning

This guide asks you to install several packages plucked from a arbitrary location on the internet, including libc (arbitrary = not a default Ubuntu package repository). These packages also are dated 2007. 

This may therefore render your system (or parts of it; think other software) unusable. Proceed with caution, if at all!

Better may be to just follow the general IRAF installation, as detailed in the IRAF documentation. This doesn't install ds9, X11IRAF or xgterm, but also doesn't require (in general) to download extra packages. 

Note that the upcoming IRAF 2.15 comes with linux 64 binaries (and essentially does away with differences between the various Linux distributions), so the problem with installation of i386 packages goes away. V2.15 is currently (sep 2010) in alpha.


# IRAF Setup on Ubuntu/Debian

This page describes how to setup IRAF on a 64-bit Ubuntu/Debian machine.
Installation of X11IRAF, DS9, Tables, and STSDAS are also included. 

It will be easiest if you just copy-paste the instructions one by one.
Please be sure to read and implement the instructions in [[brackets]] as well.

For 32-bit installation, see -
http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf_step_by_step_installation

Please send questions or comments to:
khan@astronomy.ohio-state.edu

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

sudo apt-get install tcsh

sudo apt-get install ia32-libs ia32-libs-gtk linux32

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/ldso_1.9.11-15_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i --force-architecture ldso_1.9.11-15_i386.deb

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/libc5_5.4.46-15_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i --force-architecture libc5_5.4.46-15_i386.deb

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/termcap-compat_1.2.3_i386.deb

sudo dpkg -i --force-architecture termcap-compat_1.2.3_i386.deb

[[Use System>Administration>Users and Groups to create an account with username 
"iraf", real name "IRAF Maintenance", home directory "/iraf/iraf/local", shell 
"/bin/tcsh", and a secure password. Be sure to grant admin privilege to this 
account. For sudo commands here on, use this password. An easy way to avoid 
confusion is to assign the same password to this account as to your other / 
sys-admin account.]]

[The following step didn't work for me and some fellow students. If it doesn't work, try taking away the / infront og iraf, thus sudo chown -R iraf:iraf iraf. Afterwards, take all /'s at the beginning of a path away.]

sudo chown -R iraf:iraf /iraf

su iraf

mkdir /iraf/irafbin

mkdir /iraf/irafbin/bin.linux

mkdir /iraf/irafbin/noao.bin.linux

mkdir /iraf/x11iraf

mkdir /iraf/extern

cd /iraf/iraf

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/as.pcix.gen.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/as.pcix.gen.gz  ]]

tar -zxf as.pcix.gen.gz

rm as.pcix.gen.gz

cd /iraf/iraf/unix/bin.redhat/

mv * ../bin.linux/

cd /iraf/irafbin/bin.linux

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/ib.rhux.x86.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/ib.rhux.x86.gz  ]]

tar -zxpf ib.rhux.x86.gz

rm ib.rhux.x86.gz

cd /iraf/irafbin/noao.bin.linux

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/nb.rhux.x86.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/v214/PCIX/nb.rhux.x86.gz  ]]

tar -zxpf nb.rhux.x86.gz

rm nb.rhux.x86.gz

setenv iraf /iraf/iraf/

cd $iraf/unix/hlib

source irafuser.csh

[[Choose default paths as will be shown in on-screen prompt parentheses.
Type "y" only where "yes" returns "huh?".]]

sudo ./install

sudo apt-get install libncurses5

cd /iraf/x11iraf/

wget http://iraf.net/ftp/iraf/x11iraf/x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz

[[ Alternately: wget http://iraf.noao.edu/iraf/ftp/iraf/x11iraf/x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]
 
tar -zxf x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz 

[[ Or: tar -zxf x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]

mv lib.redhat lib.linux

mv bin.redhat bin.linux

sudo ./install

rm x11iraf-v1.5DEV-bin.redhat.tar.gz

[[ Or: rm x11iraf-v2.0BETA-bin.redhat.tar.gz  ]]

wget http://hea-www.harvard.edu/saord/download/ds9/linux/ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz
 
tar -zxf ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz

rm ds9.linux.6.1.tar.gz

sudo mv ds9 /usr/local/bin/

exit

cd

wget http://geco.phys.columbia.edu/~rubab/iraf/iraf

sudo chmod u=rwx iraf

mkdir ~/IRAF

cd ~/IRAF

mkiraf

[[Select "xgterm" as your IRAF shell when prompted.]]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The command ./iraf will now launch a complete IRAF session containing DS9,
xgterm and ecl, based in ~/IRAF. Alternately, type "ecl" for enhanced IRAF, "cl"
for regular IRAF, and "ds9" for standalone DS9 launch. 

Repeat the last 5 steps for each user as needed.

The following steps show how to add external packages. This example install 
Tables and STSDAS. If you don't need extra packages, then you are done already.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

su iraf

cd /iraf/extern/

mkdir tables stsdas

cd /iraf/extern/tables/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux/

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/tables_3.11/tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm tables3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.tar.gz

cd bin.linux

wget http://stsdas.stsci.edu/download/stsdas_3.11/stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

tar -zxf stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

rm stsdas3.11.bin.redhat.tar.gz

cd /iraf/extern/stsdas

python python/compileall.py ./python

python python/compileall.py ./python/*

nano /iraf/iraf/unix/hlib/extern.pkg

[[Now, edit this file so that it look like what follows. Do not delete any 
existing lines, just add the new lines that has "stsdas" or "tables" or 
"apropos" in them.]]

-----------------------------------------

reset noao = iraf$noao/

task noao.pkg = noao$noao.cl

reset tables = /iraf/extern/tables/
task tables.pkg = tables$tables.cl

reset stsdas = /iraf/extern/stsdas/
task stsdas.pkg = stsdas$stsdas.cl
task apropos = stsdas$apropos.cl

reset helpdb = lib$helpdb.mip \
,noao$lib/helpdb.mip \
,tables$lib/helpdb.mip \
,stsdas$lib/helpdb.mip \


keep

-----------------------------------------

[[Use ctrl-x to exit, answer "y" to save file, press enter to confirm.]

exit

cd

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now, tables and stsdas are available for use inside iraf. Some of the other
commonly used packages are ared, mscred, color, ctio, fitsutil, gemini, gmisc,
nmisc, rvsao and xdimsum. Google will help you find the packages and you can set
them up (similar to the example given here for stsdas/tables) following the 
instructions of the host pages.

fields.name: iraf
fields.text:
# IRAF

Provide links to specific regarding IRAF specifics. In particular, those encountered at the API

## General

For general help, [iraf.net](http://iraf.net) is an excellent source of information. They have a forum as well!

There is also: [PyRAF - A python interface for IRAF](http://stsdas.stsci.edu/pyraf/doc.old/pyraf_tutorial/)

## IRAF Installation

### Linux workstations
Run the following script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-login

This script replaces the default login files a user gets,
when his/her account was created by the ict-people. 
The old login files are backupped and a new set of files
are installed, which are suitable for our "astro" environment.
Also some iraf settings are already in these new files.

Another script:

/home/sw-astro/DEFAULT/bin/install-default-iraf

installs a iraf sub-directoy in the user's (your) home directory. 
This directory contains all the necesary files a user needs
for using iraf.
If a user already had an iraf directory, that one will be backupped.

After you run both scripts above please logoff and login again.
(Also be sure to add 'iraf' to your [.pkgrc](pkgrc) file)

### Own machine
* [Installing IRAF on Ubuntu, 32 bit](installing_iraf_on_ubuntu)
* [Installing IRAF on Ubuntu, 64 bit](installing_iraf_on_ubuntu_64bit)


## Is there a comprehensive [IRAF manual](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/manual.pdf) around?
First of all, IRAF is such a broad and complex system, that any comprehensive manual cannot be complete and vice versa. For this university an effort has been made to write an IRAF manual. This can be downloaded [here](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/manual.pdf). 
The LaTeX source code should be available at the institute. If you think that you could contribute to to it by expanding or improving, just ask the Master coordinator or one of the authors where it can be found.

fields.name: api-calendar
fields.text:
# How to subscribe to the API calendar in iCal

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly.

## Prerequisites

A Google account.

## Instructions

1.  Go to your Google calendar at http://calendar.google.com/ and log in.
2.  Look on the left side under "My calendars". If it does not list "API", find someone who is already registered (almost everyone in the institute) and ask to be added.
3.  Click on the triangle to the right of "API" and click on "Calendar settings".
4.  Scroll down to find the line "Private Address" and click on the green iCal button.
5.  Copy the address shown, i.e. by control clicking.
6.  Open iCal and go to Calendar -> Subscribe...
7.  Paste the address after "Subscribe to:" and click on "Subscribe".
8.  The calendar should now be added to your own.

For the pizza lunch calendar start with step 6. and copy the following address: webcal://www.google.com/calendar/ical/nhu5qvbil1rj987m991hn1lork%40group.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics

fields.name: regular_events
fields.text:
# How to enjoy your time at the API

There are a lot of activities going on at the institute, but some can be a bit obscure to newcomers. This how-to lists most of them, so you have no excuse to hide in your office all day.

## Daily

**11:00ish Coffee break**
:    Gather at the coffee table and talk about whatever you want with whomever you want. Free coffee and tea and occasionally biscuits, cake, sweets, pies...

**13:00ish Lunch**
:    Round up your officemates, go to the canteen on the ground floor, buy your lunch (or bring your own) and find a nice table to join.

## Weekly

The [API agenda](/internal/agenda) has an up-to-date schedule of events, including speaker names and abstracts for the colloquia and pizza lunches.

**Tuesday 16:00 Journal Club**
:    APIs get together in the Pannekoek room to discuss recent papers. Sometimes there is tea to share, other times sweets are brought. Email Daniela to get on the list for reminder emails.

**Wednesday 10:30 Info coffee**
:    At infocoffee Ralph Wijers will update us all on new employees, guests and topical changes in our institute.

**Wednesday 15:30 Colloquium**
:    Most Wednesdays there is a colloquium by a staff member of another institute. This is considered part of the programme for students. Afterwards there is a little borrel with wine and cheese and juice in the API common room.

**Thursday 12:00 Pizza lunch**
:    Two people from the institute will give a talk, one a few minutes, the other around half an hour, on either their own research or on a topic of their interest in the colloquium room. Afterwards there is room for discussion.

**Friday 17:00ish Whisky break**
:    This is possibly the best way to get to know your fellow APIs. Almost every week, in the common room, the advertised drink is served, and the company enjoyed. Occasionally, GRAPPA crashes/joins us for whisky break.


## Occasional

**Group meetings**
:    Research groups or interest groups of varying specificity have regular (or semi-regular) meetings, such as high energy astro, low energy astro, and X-ray timing. Ask your supervisor or someone in a similar field which meetings they attend, and who to contact to get on the email list. [GRAPPA](http://grappa.science.uva.nl/) also has a mailing list if you're interested in astro-particle physics and cosmology -- email their secretariat to get on the list. It's also a good idea to get on your relevant [NOVA research network](http://www.nova-astronomy.nl/Research.php) mailing list.

**Beta Break**
:    [Beta Break](http://www.betabreak.nl/) (website in Dutch) is a monthly event during the main academic year where a few academics from different fields have a discussion about the advertised topic. This takes place between the coffee bar and the elevators on the ground floor of the building. Recently the events have been in English.

**Afternoon tea break**
:    Very informal break, enjoyed by a few people. If you want to enter this select company, talk to Martin. It doesn't happen very frequently, but it is another time to offer cake if someone else has beaten you to the morning coffee break. There are also some tea aficionados (e.g., Abbie, Daniela, Lucy, etc.) who have a daily tea break either just after lunch or sometime in the afternoon.

**Evening drinks**
:    To celebrate the end of another successful week (sometimes just the end of a day), on most Fridays a group of people leave the institute to indulge in drink and happiness. The location changes, but it usually takes place in "De Polder" or "Oerknal" next door, "Brouwerij 't IJ" (known as The Windmill) or "The East of Eden".

**Nerd Nite**
:    Some APIs have been known to present at or attend [Amsterdam Nerd Nite](http://amsterdam.nerdnite.com/). All Nerd Nite events are held in English. Check the website for when the next one is and ask around to see who else is going. Posters for the upcoming Nerd Nite are usually posted in the coffee area.

**Birthdays**
:    On an API's birthday, it is their responsibility to bring in cake (or other sweets) to share with the institute at morning coffee break. They will send out an email to the institute alerting everyone that today is their birthday and they brought cake.

## Branching out

**Dutch courses**
:    The UvA offers a variety of [Dutch courses](http://intt.uva.nl/dutch-for-foreigners/nav) for foreigners at different levels and intensities. Abbie, Cátia, Riley, and Phil (among others) have taken some of these courses, so you can ask them questions if you're considering taking one.

**Meetups**
:    A nice way to meet people in Amsterdam with similar interests is through [meetups](http://amsterdam.meetup.com/). Sign up for groups and events that sound interesting!

**Universum Sports Centre**
:    Sports and exercise classes at [Universum](http://www.usc.uva.nl/algemeen/index_en.php), right next door in Science Park, are also a nice way to have fun and make friends! All exercise classes are conducted in Dutch, but nearly all the instructors speak English and are happy to accommodate non-Dutch-speakers.

**English-language events**
:    [i amsterdam](http://www.iamsterdam.com/en-GB/living/Expatcenter/expatcenter-partners) has a list of media and events partners that specifically cater to the English-speaking expat community (scroll down to 'Media & events' at the link). Most of these have a newsletter or forum to stay up-to-date.

**The American Book Center**
:    The [American Book Center](http://www.abc.nl/), in the city center, is one of a few bookstores in Amsterdam that sell English-language books and magazines. They also have a social calendar (with events like American Thanksgiving) and a bi-annual book sale that is not to be missed. 


Of course this is only the proverbial tip of the iceberg. Check the [API agenda](/internal/agenda), or become a member of the [API Google calendar](mac_os_x-ical-api_calendar) for more events, or add your own.
fields.html:
How to enjoy your time at the API

There are a lot of activities going on at the institute, but some can be a bit obscure to newcomers. This how-to lists most of them, so you have no excuse to hide in your office all day.

Daily

11:00ish Coffee break
Gather at the coffee table and talk about whatever you want with whomever you want. Free coffee and tea and occasionally biscuits, cake, sweets, pies...
13:00ish Lunch
Round up your officemates, go to the canteen on the ground floor, buy your lunch (or bring your own) and find a nice table to join.

Weekly

The API agenda has an up-to-date schedule of events, including speaker names and abstracts for the colloquia and pizza lunches.

Tuesday 16:00 Journal Club
APIs get together in the Pannekoek room to discuss recent papers. Sometimes there is tea to share, other times sweets are brought. Email Daniela to get on the list for reminder emails.
Wednesday 10:30 Info coffee
At infocoffee Ralph Wijers will update us all on new employees, guests and topical changes in our institute.
Wednesday 15:30 Colloquium
Most Wednesdays there is a colloquium by a staff member of another institute. This is considered part of the programme for students. Afterwards there is a little borrel with wine and cheese and juice in the API common room.
Thursday 12:00 Pizza lunch
Two people from the institute will give a talk, one a few minutes, the other around half an hour, on either their own research or on a topic of their interest in the colloquium room. Afterwards there is room for discussion.
Friday 17:00ish Whisky break
This is possibly the best way to get to know your fellow APIs. Almost every week, in the common room, the advertised drink is served, and the company enjoyed. Occasionally, GRAPPA crashes/joins us for whisky break.

fields.name: e-mail_alias
fields.text:
# Creating an e-mail alias

To make an e-mail alias (an additional e-mail address (just a label) that acts as if the e-mail had been send to your standard e-mail address) for your UvA e-mail address, follow the following steps:

* Go to [http://www.ic.uva.nl/uvanetid](http://www.ic.uva.nl/uvanetid)
* Click on: "[Inloggen accountbeheer voor medewerkers/gelieerden](https://accountbeheer.medewerker.uva.nl:3080/user)"
* Log in with your UvAnetID and corresponding password.
* Click on: E-mail account
* Your alias has to at least contain your last name, but you can add characters to the front and apparently even to the back of your name (Example: A.B.Cee@uva.nl can become cee@uva.nl, AbeCee@uva.nl, Ceedog@uva.nl, etcetera).
* Fill in (for example) only your last name before @uva.nl and click on "Opslaan" (save). If the e-mail address hasn't been claimed yet (some people have the same last name and can therefore claim identical aliases) you'll get a message that it might take 1/2 a day to synchronise the server (i.e. before you can use it).

Small drawback: the spam will be redirected as well. Your choice.

Small drawback: the spam will be redirected as well. Your choice.

fields.name: e-mail_forwarding
fields.text:
# Setting up e-mail forwarding

If you'd like to forward your UvA e-mail, either because you want all your mail in one place or for security, follow these steps:

* Go to [https://id.uva.nl/](https://id.uva.nl/)
* Log in with your UvAnetID and corresponding password.
* Click on "profile"
* Enter the e-mail address you want to forward your mail to after "Mailrouting address"
* Click on "Save"/"Opslaan" and log out.

Small drawback: the spam will be forwarded as well. Your choice.

fields.name: latex_acronyms
fields.text:
# Acronyms in LaTeX

Especially in scientific literature many acronyms pop up. To deal with them in a consistent way, the acronym package has been created. This package will write out the acronym the first time it is used and write it as an acronym for the rest of the article. A short introduction follows, with a link to the full manual at the bottom.

## Introduction

### Loading the package

To load the package, add \\usepackage{acronym} after the documentclass and before \\begin{document}.
Defining the acronyms

You can define acronyms with \\acrodef{label}[acronym]{written out form}, for example \\acrodef{etacar}[$\\eta$ Car]{Eta Carinae}, with the restriction that the label should be simple ASCII. If label and acronym are the same, just use \\acronym{SN}{supernova}.

### Using the acronyms

The standard command to use an acronym is \\ac{label}. The first time you use this, the acronym will be written in full with the acronym in parentheses: supernova (SN). At later times it will just print the acronym: SN.

#### Other commands

\\acresetall
:    resets all acronyms to not used. Useful after the abstract to redefine all acronyms in the introduction.
\\acf{label}
:    written out form with acronym in parentheses, irrespective of previous use
\\acs{label}
:    acronym form, irrespective of previous use
\\acl{label}
:    written out form without following acronym
\\acp{label}
:    plural form of acronym by adding an s. \\acfp. \\acsp, \\aclp work as well.

## Manual

[Acronym package manual](http://www.ctan.org/tex-archive/macros/latex/contrib/acronym/acronym.pdf)

fields.name: linux_ls_colour
fields.text:
# How to colour your directory listings

## Basics

First, ensure you are using GNU ls. That's the default on (most?) Linux systems, but not eg. MacOS:

    $ ls --version
    ls (GNU coreutils) 8.19

Then, simply run:

    $ ls --color=auto

in a terminal. You can add it to your aliases to replace ls or create a new command (lc, for example).

## Customization

### The easy way

You can customize the colours used in one of two ways. First, you can change how your terminal interprets the colours it's asked to draw: "blue" (for example) obviously covers a multitude of hues, and most terminal emulators will let you tweak exactly which one they use. You'll have to refer to your terminal emulator's documentation for help with this, though.

### The hard way

Secondly, you can set the environment variable `$LS_COLORS`. Unfortunately, configuring this properly can be rather awkward, but you can use the `dircolors` command for help. Refer to its man page for full details (ie, type `man dircolors`). Run it with the `-p` option to print an example configuration file which you can tweak to your liking. Save the result to a file (`~/.dircolors` is traditional), as shown:

    $ dircolors -p > ~/.dircolors

Open it in your favourite text editor and scroll to below all the TERM nonsense. Here is the bit:

    # Below are the color init strings for the basic file types. A color init
    # string consists of one or more of the following numeric codes:
    # Attribute codes: 
    # 00=none 01=bold 04=underscore 05=blink 07=reverse 08=concealed
    # Text color codes:
    # 30=black 31=red 32=green 33=yellow 34=blue 35=magenta 36=cyan 37=white
    # Background color codes:
    # 40=black 41=red 42=green 43=yellow 44=blue 45=magenta 46=cyan 47=white
    NORMAL 00       # global default, although everything should be something.
    FILE 00         # normal file
    DIR 01;34       # directory
    LINK 01;36      # symbolic link
    FIFO 40;33      # pipe
    SOCK 01;35      # socket
    BLK 40;33;01    # block device driver
    CHR 40;33;01    # character device driver
    ORPHAN 01;05;37;41  # orphaned syminks
    MISSING 01;05;37;41 # ... and the files they point to

It's that pesky DIR 01;34 that's the problem. As you can see, you can add attributes, text colour and background colour to a certain file type by separating the corresponding numbers by semicolons. Below this you can even associate colours with file extensions.

Most systems are configured to automatically set things up according to `~/.dircolors` when you log in. If yours isn't, you'll need to edit your shell initialization scripts to invoke it appropriately.

fields.name: emacs_python
fields.text:
# How to get Emacs 22 to automatically indent python code

*Overall note: this is so generic and not API related, it may be better to defer to external websites instead.*


This HowTo is written for Emacs version 22.1.1. Other versions might differ slightly.

Emacs version 21 automatically indented Python code out of the box. In version 22 some work has to be done to get the same behaviour. The following website was used for this HowTo: [http://www.emacswiki.org/cgi-bin/wiki/PythonMode](http://www.emacswiki.org/cgi-bin/wiki/PythonMode).


Quick note [*added by Evert, Nov 2011*]: emacs 22 should have its own python mode installed by default, but not the traditional python-mode.el (instead, it's called [python.el](http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ProgrammingWithPythonDotEl): this version should deal better with triple quotes syntax highlighting, for example; the only possible caveat is that <return> not automatically indents as well; <ctrl-j> does that now. There is [a solution](http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ProgrammingWithPythonDotEl#toc1) for that, of course. (warning: python-mode.el may still be referred to in your .emacs.d/init.el and clobber things.)


## Download Emacs mode

* Create the folder elisp in your home directory.
* Download python-mode.el from [https://launchpad.net/python-mode](https://launchpad.net/python-mode) to that folder. [Direct link to version 5.1.0](http://launchpad.net/python-mode/trunk/5.1.0/+download/python-mode.el)

## In your .emacs file:

* Open your .emacs file in a text editor
* Copy the folowing code to your .emacs file

        (if (fboundp 'normal-top-level-add-subdirs-to-load-path)
            (let* ((my-lisp-dir "~/elisp/")
                  (default-directory my-lisp-dir))
               (setq load-path (cons my-lisp-dir load-path))
               (normal-top-level-add-subdirs-to-load-path)))

* Also copy the following snippet:

        (autoload 'python-mode "python-mode" "Python Mode." t)
        (add-to-list 'auto-mode-alist '("\\.py\\'" . python-mode))
        (add-to-list 'interpreter-mode-alist '("python" . python-mode))

* Save the .emacs file and reload Emacs. It should now indent correctly.

fields.name: heasoft
fields.text:
# HEASoft

## Introduction

HEASoft is a software suite consisting of the union of FTOOLS/FV, XIMAGE, XRONOS, XSPEC and XSTAR. It is used to analyse Swift and RXTE observations. The current version is 6.14 as of 30-Oct-2013, when this page was last updated. You want the source install. 

## Configuration for Linux
These Linux directions are from when HEASoft was in version 6.5.

Add the following lines to your .aliases file located in your home directory:

    # Heasoft aliases
    alias   start_xray      'source ${HEADAS}/headas-init.csh'

Because other programs sometimes use the same name for libraries that are not related, you are advised to type "start_xray" in a terminal where you will only use HEASoft programs and use different terminals for other programs.

If you don't know whether your machine is 32- or 64-bit, type "uname -a" in a terminal and if the returned line contains "x86_64" your machine is 64-bit.

If you have a 64-bit system add the following lines in your .pkgrc file located in your home directory:

    caldb
    xray64

If you have a 32-bit system add the following lines in your .pkgrc file located in your home directory:

    caldb
    xray

There might be issues with the 64-bit version. If you encounter a problem, contact the ICT-contact person.

##Starting from Scratch on a Mac
The following is compiled by Abbie, after much trial and tribulation, for Mac OS X 10.8.5. If at any point something doesn't make sense, ask Abbie or someone else or google it, and we'll help you and update the wiki.

Note that my personal preferences are for macports and bash, so that's what this is written for. If you prefer fink or homebrew, or the c-shell, modify these guidelines accordingly. I specify if you should install something with macports, and if I don't say 'use macports' then I did it manually.

### Things you need to download/install and do, in order:
:    1) Install XQuartz
:    2) Install Xcode (need version 4.6.3, since 5 doesn't work for HEASoft)
:    3) Get Xcode command line tools (Xcode -> Preferences -> Downloads -> Install cmd line tools)
:    4) Install Java dev. package (I don't remember if this is necessary, but I did it here and my HEASoft works, so why not)
:    5) Install Macports
:    6) Now add /opt/local/bin, /opt/local/sbin, and /usr/bin to your path variable in bashrc
:    7) selfupdate macports
:    8) Use macports to install: intltool, gawk, libtool, automake, mawk, pkgconfig
:    9) Install libpng
:    10) Use macports to install: libgc, GMP, MPFR, MPC, wget, g95, cairo, Lzip, pango, nawk, ncurses, gmake
:    11) Install LittleCMS (again, I don't remember if this is necessary, but I did it at this point in the install process, or actually after g95 and before cairo, and my HEASoft works)
:    12) Install gcc 4.7 + universal using macports
:    13) Set paths for gcc, g++, and perl in bashrc using the /usr/bin paths (these ones were downloaded with Xcode & command line tools), and set gfortran using the /opt/local/bin path (this one was downloaded with gcc 4.7 with macports)
:    14) Make a directory /usr/local/src: 'sudo mkdir /usr/local/src'
:    15) Use macports to install readline
:    16) Install S-Lang in /usr/local/src (download tarball, open it, move that folder into /usr/local/src, and then follow install instructions)
:    17) Use the 'ln' command to link wget into the /usr/bin
:    18) Use macports to install pgplot
:    19) Install SLIRP, slxfig, and SLStats manually into /usr/local/src
:    20) In a terminal window type 'sudo -E bash', so that you're a root user (check with 'whoami')
:    21) Download the HEASoft tarball from the HEASARC website. Move the opened tarball folder to /usr/local/src, and open the install instructions and follow along. You're doing the source install. When installing, you need to specify where x11 is like the example in the install instructions. The install shouldn't take more than a few hours maximum.
: ###References:
* [Black-hole.eu](http://www.black-hole.eu/index.php/schools-workshops-and-conferences/2nd-school-on-multiwavelength-astronomy/course-materials/142-software-instructions-for-mac0s-105-a-106)
* [HEASoft support](http://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/lheasoft/support.html#Mac10.8)
fields.html:
HEASoft

Introduction

HEASoft is a software suite consisting of the union of FTOOLS/FV, XIMAGE, XRONOS, XSPEC and XSTAR. It is used to analyse Swift and RXTE observations. The current version is 6.14 as of 30-Oct-2013, when this page was last updated. You want the source install.

Configuration for Linux

These Linux directions are from when HEASoft was in version 6.5.

Add the following lines to your .aliases file located in your home directory:

# Heasoft aliases
alias   start_xray      'source ${HEADAS}/headas-init.csh'

Because other programs sometimes use the same name for libraries that are not related, you are advised to type "start_xray" in a terminal where you will only use HEASoft programs and use different terminals for other programs.

If you don't know whether your machine is 32- or 64-bit, type "uname -a" in a terminal and if the returned line contains "x86_64" your machine is 64-bit.

If you have a 64-bit system add the following lines in your .pkgrc file located in your home directory:

caldb
xray64

If you have a 32-bit system add the following lines in your .pkgrc file located in your home directory:

caldb
xray

There might be issues with the 64-bit version. If you encounter a problem, contact the ICT-contact person.

Starting from Scratch on a Mac

The following is compiled by Abbie, after much trial and tribulation, for Mac OS X 10.8.5. If at any point something doesn't make sense, ask Abbie or someone else or google it, and we'll help you and update the wiki.

Note that my personal preferences are for macports and bash, so that's what this is written for. If you prefer fink or homebrew, or the c-shell, modify these guidelines accordingly. I specify if you should install something with macports, and if I don't say 'use macports' then I did it manually.

Things you need to download/install and do, in order:

1) Install XQuartz
2) Install Xcode (need version 4.6.3, since 5 doesn't work for HEASoft)
3) Get Xcode command line tools (Xcode -> Preferences -> Downloads -> Install cmd line tools)
4) Install Java dev. package (I don't remember if this is necessary, but I did it here and my HEASoft works, so why not)
5) Install Macports
6) Now add /opt/local/bin, /opt/local/sbin, and /usr/bin to your path variable in bashrc
7) selfupdate macports
8) Use macports to install: intltool, gawk, libtool, automake, mawk, pkgconfig
9) Install libpng
10) Use macports to install: libgc, GMP, MPFR, MPC, wget, g95, cairo, Lzip, pango, nawk, ncurses, gmake
11) Install LittleCMS (again, I don't remember if this is necessary, but I did it at this point in the install process, or actually after g95 and before cairo, and my HEASoft works)
12) Install gcc 4.7 + universal using macports
13) Set paths for gcc, g++, and perl in bashrc using the /usr/bin paths (these ones were downloaded with Xcode & command line tools), and set gfortran using the /opt/local/bin path (this one was downloaded with gcc 4.7 with macports)
14) Make a directory /usr/local/src: 'sudo mkdir /usr/local/src'
15) Use macports to install readline
16) Install S-Lang in /usr/local/src (download tarball, open it, move that folder into /usr/local/src, and then follow install instructions)
17) Use the 'ln' command to link wget into the /usr/bin
18) Use macports to install pgplot
19) Install SLIRP, slxfig, and SLStats manually into /usr/local/src
20) In a terminal window type 'sudo -E bash', so that you're a root user (check with 'whoami')
21) Download the HEASoft tarball from the HEASARC website. Move the opened tarball folder to /usr/local/src, and open the install instructions and follow along. You're doing the source install. When installing, you need to specify where x11 is like the example in the install instructions. The install shouldn't take more than a few hours maximum.

References:

  • Black-hole.eu
  • HEASoft support

fields.name: mac_os_x-ical-api_calendar
fields.text:
# How to subscribe to the API calendar in iCal

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly.

## Prerequisites

A Google account.

## Instructions

1.  Go to your [Google calendar](http://calendar.google.com/) and log in.
2.  Look on the left side under "My calendars". If it does not list "API", find someone who is already registered (almost everyone in the institute) and ask to be added.
3.  Click on the triangle to the right of "API" and click on "Calendar settings".
4.  Scroll down to find the line "Private Address" and click on the green iCal button.
5.  Copy the address shown, i.e. by control clicking.
6.  Open iCal and go to Calendar -> Subscribe...
7.  Paste the address after "Subscribe to:" and click on "Subscribe".
8.  The calendar should now be added to your own.

For the pizza lunch calendar start with step 6. and copy the following address: [webcal://www.google.com/calendar/ical/nhu5qvbil1rj987m991hn1lork%40group.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics](webcal://www.google.com/calendar/ical/nhu5qvbil1rj987m991hn1lork%40group.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics)

fields.name: mac_os_x-preview-extracting_text_from_pdf
fields.text:
# How to extract text or images from PDF files

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly.

If you want to copy text or extract an image from a PDF without losing the vector information, following these instructions.
One caveat is that the PDF files should be well written PDF.

## Extracting text:

* Open the PDF file in Preview.
* Select the text tool in the upper right corner (Command-2).
* Select the text in the PDF.
* Copy the selection to the Clipboard (Command-C).
* Open a text file and paste the contents of the Clipboard (Command-V).

## Extracting an image:

* Open the PDF file in Preview.
* Select the select tool in the upper right corner (Command-3).
* Draw a selection box in the PDF. You can adjust it afterwards.
* Copy the selection to the Clipboard (Command-C).
* Open a new PDF file with the contents of the Clipboard (Command-N).
* Save this new file as a PDF.

fields.name: mac_os_x-keyboard_viewer
fields.text:
# How to get an interactive Keyboard Viewer

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly.

## Instructions

Since Mac OS X can provide you with a large number of symbols that are sometimes hidden behind a couple of simultaneous keystrokes, it would be nice to see what every key would give you if you press a function key or two, mainly option and shift. There is a small program that does this for you, but it is itself a bit hidden. This program will also show you in orange the keys (e,u,i,`,n) that produce the accents on letters, if you press option.

* Go to the System Preferences and click on "International".
* Click on the tab "Input Menu".
* In the list, click on the check box next to "Keyboard Viewer" and also check "Show input menu in menu bar". Here you can also select different keyboard layouts for swift switching.
* Whenever you want the Keyboard Viewer click on the flag in the menu bar and choose "Show Keyboard Viewer".

fields.name: mac_os_x-mail-uva_mail
fields.text:
# How to add an e-mail account to Mail

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly (but verified for 10.6).

## Instructions

If you want to read your e-mail (UvA / Gmail) from within Mail and not having to log in to a webpage, follow these steps (text between < > is a description of what should be filled in, everything else is literal):

1.  If you open the program Mail for the very first time it will immediately ask you to add a new account. Otherwise go to File -> Add Account...
2.  Fill in the following information:  
    **General Information**  
    Account Type: IMAP  
    Account Description: UvA / Gmail / <Whatever you want to call the account>  
    Full Name: <Your own name that will be used as the name of the sender>  
    Email Address: <Your e-mail address for this account>
3.  Click on Continue
4.  Fill in the following information:  
    **Incoming Mail Server**  
    Incoming Mail Server: imap.uva.nl / imap.gmail.com  
    User Name: <The username for this e-mail address> (For the UvA, this your login name on eg the selfservice webpages, so something like erol1. Not your email address or your science account.)
    Password: <The password for this e-mail address/login>
5.  Click on Continue
6.  Fill in the following information:  
    **Outgoing Mail Server**  
    Outgoing Mail Server: smtp.uva.nl / smtp.gmail.com  
    Use Authentication: Checked  
    User Name: <The username for this e-mail address> (For the UvA, same remarks as above) 
    Password: <The password for this e-mail address>
7.  Click on Continue
8.  Click on Done

# Plain text in TextEdit

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly.

##In new files

To have every new file start with plain text, go to the preferences (command-,) and in the New file tab, click the radio button before plain text.

## In existing files

To convert rich text to plain text, choose Layout->Convert to plain text, or type shift-command-t.

fields.name: mac_os_x-printing-setup
fields.text:
# Printing setup on Mac OS X

There are two ways of installing the printer on your Mac: via the generic driver, or via the Oce driver that gives more functionality (such as stapling). The generic driver is easier to set up, but does not support colour printing and previously has been reported to malfunction when attempting to print colour pdfs on the old colour printer, P005204.

Go to System Preferences -> Print & Fax -> Click the + button -> Make sure the selected tab is IP.

## Generic driver

The settings you need are:

- Address: uvaprint.uva.nl
- Protocol: LPD
- Queue: P005205   (and variants thereof for other printers)
- Name and Location: whatever you'd like them to be
- Use: Generic PCL Printer
- Be sure to tick the option "Duplex unit" (you can always choose single-sided printing later, when printing). Note that double-sided printing has been reported not to work in some cases.

Note: if you are running OS X 10.9 (Maverick), the Oce printer drivers can cause Mail, Safari and Preview to crash. Using the generic driver appears to work fine.

## Oce printer drivers

The UvA supplies instructions on how to install the printer driver on the [UvA employee webpage](http://staff.uva.nl/science/az/item/printers.html).
Unfortunately they do not completely work, and you have to combine information from two manuals.

-  Download the printer drivers by going directly to:
[http://www.oce.nl/support/](http://www.oce.nl/support/) and click on "Drivers en downloads" and look for the driver you want to appropriate for your operating system. For OS X 10.8, just use the 10.7 option. For instance:

> Oce VarioLink 3622c: for P005007 (colour, by the red toilets)

> Oce VarioLink 3622: for P005205 (black and white, by the green toilets)


-  Install the printer drivers. The pkg installers are within the sub-folders of what you downloaded from the Oce website.

-  Back in setting up the printer in system preferences (following the far-above instructions), when selecting the use or driver (under 'Select Printer Software...'), use 'GENERIC 36C-1 PS' for p005007 and 'GENERIC 36BW-2 PS' for p005203 and p005205. 

-  If the printer doesn't print double-sided by default, select '2-Sided' under 'Layout/Finish' in the print menu, and save this under presets.

fields.name: mac_os_x-wireless-setup
fields.text:
# Getting wireless to work on Mac OS X


[ICT instructions for eduroam](http://student.uva.nl/eco/az/item/wireless-internet.html)

## How to connect? 

To establish a connection to the UvA wireless network you will first need to install the SecureW2 security software on your device (laptop, tablet or smartphone). 

## If you already have an Internet connection (e.g. mobile Internet) 

Go to [www.wifiportal.uva.nl](https://www.wifiportal.uva.nl). This page checks your operating system to ensure you download the right software (e.g. for Windows, Mac OS X or Android). Check to see if the right operating system is selected and click JoinNow. The SecureW2 software will now be downloaded. Install the software on your device.

## If you are at a UvA location 

Establish a connection with the UvAguests wireless network. Once your connection has been established, open your Internet browser and go to [www.wifiportal.uva.nl](https://www.wifiportal.uva.nl) (Internet Explorer will direct you to this page automatically). This page checks your operating system to ensure you download the right software (e.g. for Windows, Mac OS X or Android). Check to see if the right operating system is selected and click JoinNow. The SecureW2 software will now be downloaded. Install the software on your device.

## After installing the software 

Once you have installed the SecureW2 software you can start using wireless internet at the UvA by selecting the ‘eduroam’ wireless network and logging in with 'yourUvAnetID@uva.nl' as your username, and your UvAnet password as your password.
