fields.name: mac_os_x-address_book-ldap
fields.text:
# How to access the LDAP server in Address Book
(last update: 14 June 2013)

This HowTo was written for Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger). Other versions might differ slightly although the requested information should be the same.

By configuring an LDAP server in Address Book, it is possible to search for people working and studying at the UvA by typing in part of their name.


You have to be in the UvA network or be connected via VPN to have access to the server. The student server does not seem to work anymore, but its description is kept for completeness.

## Configuring Address Book

* Open Address Book and go to the preferences (Command-,).
* Click on the LDAP tab (the book with an i and a magnifying glass).
* Add a server by clicking on the plus sign in the bottom left.
* For employees fill in the following information and press "Save":  
  Name: Uva Employees (or any other label)  
  Server: ldap1.uva.nl  
  Search Base: ou=Medewerkers,o=Universiteit van Amsterdam,c=NL  
  Port: 389 ("Use SSL" should be unchecked.)  
  Scope: Subtree  
  Auth type: None
* For students fill in the following information and press "Save":  
  Name: Uva Students (or any other label)  
  Server: ldap1.uva.nl  
  Search Base: ou=Studenten,o=Universiteit van Amsterdam,c=NL  
  Port: 389 ("Use SSL" should be unchecked.)  
  Scope: Subtree  
  Auth type: None
* Close the preferences.
* In the Group list click on Directories.
* Optionally select a specific directory or select All.
* In the search box (top right) you can type part of a name.
* After a second or two all matches will be displayed and you can double click them for more information or drag them to your groups to import them.

fields.name: mac_os_x-installation-gnuplot
fields.text:
# Installing GNUplot

## MacPorts
First install MacPorts:

*   Go to the [install page](http://www.macports.org/install.php) of the [MacPorts](http://www.macports.org/) web site.
*   Click on the type of OS X ([Snow Leopard](http://distfiles.macports.org/MacPorts/MacPorts-1.9.2-10.6-SnowLeopard.dmg), [Leopard](http://distfiles.macports.org/MacPorts/MacPorts-1.9.2-10.5-Leopard.dmg) or [Tiger](http://distfiles.macports.org/MacPorts/MacPorts-1.9.1-10.4-Tiger.dmg)) link after the first bullet point; MacPorts will download and install; just answer a few questions.
*   Do an update of MacPorts from within a terminal. If you are not an administrator use "su" to change to one. Then type

        sudo port -v selfupdate

    and provide the administrator password.


## GNUplot
Simply type the following (as an administrator):

    sudo port install gnuplot

and provide the administrator password.
This might take the better part of an hour to complete due to dependencies.

GNUplot will be installed at /opt/local/bin/gnuplot and your path will be updated.

# Installing TextWrangler

TextWrangler is a free powerful text editor by [Bare Bones Software](http://www.barebones.com/) that among many other features supports multi-file search, text-colouring, grep-based search and replace and column pasting and also opens almost any file. You can download it here: [http://www.barebones.com/products/TextWrangler/download.html](http://www.barebones.com/products/TextWrangler/download.html)

To connect via VPN to the uva, you need at least MacOS X 10.6 (SnowLeopard) and a separate client. As of April 15, 2013, the built-in Cisco VPN client doesn't work anymore. Please refer to the instructions at the [uva website](http://www.ic.uva.nl/ic/object.cfm/153E2A28-B3A3-4DFF-87E9E275056FEDC6)

fields.name: remote-execution
fields.text:
# Remote execution

The linux cluster that most of the computers in the institute are part of (including student machines) is set up in such a way that you can easily use computing power from others machines in the cluster. You can access those machines via ssh and store data via the scratch drives mounted in `/net`, see [accessing a computer remotely](remote-access).  
(note that this might change when the institute switches to self-support somewhere in 2011)

## Being nice
Although the computing power of the cluster is available to everyone, please make sure that other people can still do their work if you are running a program on their machine. Therefore, nice or renice your program, such that they only take up cpu power that is not used by the system or main user. If you normally launch a program via:  
`command [arguments]`  
you can give it a lower priority by launching it with:  
`nice +19 command [arguments]`  
or  
`nice -n 19 command [arguments]`  
depending on what kind of terminal you use. Renice-ing to 19 gives your process lowest priority, so you do not stall the computer even if you use 100% CPU.

Note that nice only works for CPU, not memory! If you want to use all available memory, make sure no-one else uses the machine you want to use.

## How can I log out but keep my processes running?
You have to run the proces in background running mode by adding an ampersand `&` after your command:  
`command [arguments] &`  
If command produces any output, you have to redirect this to a file using `>&`, else the program crashes after logout.  
`command [arguments] >& file &`  
(note that a '>' alone also redirects the output, but not any error messages)

You can also send a program that is running in the foreground to the bakground. Use `bg` to do this.  
`ctr-z`  
`bg`  
will suspend the process you are running and put in in `background` running mode.  
`fg`  
will get it to the foreground so you can interact with the process again.

It is also possible to send active processes to the foreground or background by using their job ID. A job is a process which has been started from the current shell. To get a list of the running jobs, just type 
`jobs`  
The output will look somewhat like this:  
`[1]     Running                       firefox`  
`[2]     Suspended                     kile`  
`[3]   + Running                       xmms`   
`[4]   - Running                       nedit`  
	
To send nedit to the foreground, just type  
`fg [4]`  

## How can I log out but keep my processes running using the 'screen' command? 
The `screen` command allows you to create a linux terminal which stays running in the background. It is possible to log the output in a file while the process is running. To start a new session of `screen` just type  
`screen`  
Screen will start up. You can now just do as if it were a normal terminal. When you want to start logging the in- and output, just press `ctrl-a H`. From now on, all output will be dumped in a file called `screenlog.0`. Then, you can simply `detach` the screen session by pressing `ctrl-a d`. Everything will continue running and logging, even when you log out and in again. To continue working from the screen you left, just type  
`screen -r`  
This will `reattach` the screen and you will be able to continue issuing commands to it. If you have multiple screens running, this command will tell you that it does not know which one to reattach to.  
`screen -r`  
`There are several suitable screens on:`  
`32426.pts-1.astro    (Detached)`  
`32514.pts-1.astro    (Detached)`  
Type `screen [-d] -r [pid.]tty.host` to resume one of them.  
	
You will then have to specify which session of `screen` you want to reattach to.  
`screen -r 32426`  
To end a `screen` session, just type  
`exit`  
from within that session.  
`Screen` offers a lot of other interesting features, like working together in the same session. Just have a look at [this webpage](http://www.bangmoney.org/presentations/screen.html).

fields.name: api-faq
fields.text:
# Linux basics for students / old api-faq

This is a quick linux intro for new students taken from the old [api-faq](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/index_2010_12_30). The old F.A.Q will disappear once it is integrated into the current wiki.

## Institute specific
### How do I get computer support?
First, ask your colleagues or fellow students, they often have encountered a similar problem before. Second, check this wiki. Third, you can also send an email to the 
servicedesk-ic@uva.nl or call 2200?? .

### how do I check my disk quota?
open a terminal and type  
`quota -v`

If you have exceeded your disk quota, you cannot login anymore. Type Ctrl+Alt+F1 (F2 to F6 also work) to switch to a non-graphical environment. Log in using your normal username and password and (re)move some files from your home folder until you use disk space below your quota. Log out (typing exit) and type Ctrl+Alt+F7 to switch back to the graphical environment.
If the above doesn't work, ask someone if you can login remotely from their computer to delete some files.

### Where can I find more disk space?
each computer has one or two harddrives mounted in scratch. See [remote access](remote-access) on how to acces them.

## printing
### What's the print command? 
On linux it's `lpr -Pprintername`. Note that you can only print postscript files this way, not pdf!
You can set the standard print destination with 

setenv PRINTER p005204
setenv LPDEST  p005204    

in your ~/.env.csh file.

### What's the printer called?
The printer in the API kitchen is called p005204, the black and white printer in the ITFA kitchen is called p005203

## Linux General 
### How can I change the permission settings of one of my directories such that others can read from or write to it? 
Use `chmod` to do this.  
`chmod -R ug+rw dir`  
will change the permissions of all files and directories in dir such that you (u) and the members of your group (g) can read (r) and write (w) to it. The same can be achieved with a numerical expression  
`chmod -R 755 dir`

### How can I see how much space is availble on a scratch disk? 
Use df to do this.  
`df -h /scratch`  
The output will yield the size, empty and available space on the disk.

### How do I kill the X server or log into a locked desktop?
Press `ctrl-alt-backspace`. This is also worth a try if all you see is a mouse pointer or when the computer seems to be very slow for unknown reasons.

## animations
### How do I produce an animation (mpeg) from a collection of images?
[Mencoder](http://www.mplayerhq.hu/homepage/design7/dload.html), the encoder bundled with Mplayer can do this. The commandline options are a bit complicated, so [here](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/animate.pl) is a perl script to automate the process (which can take some time).

Example usage:  
`perl animate.pl --dir ~/images -l 0 -u 0100 -i picture -o animation.mpg`  
will produce an mpeg file called `animation.mpg' (-o, output) from the files numbered `0000' (-l, lower) to `0100' (-u, upper) in directory `~/images' and with filebase `picture' (-i, input). Some other option are: `-s 0.5' to scale the images to half their original size, `-v' to turn on verbosity and `--codec mpeg4' to use the mpeg4 codec. By default this script will produce mpeg files that can be embedded in presentations. The most basic call is  
perl animate.pl -o animation.mpg  
and will produce an mpeg file called `animation.mpg' from all of the picture files (matching ones, favoured by volume) in the current directory. More options are given in the source code (framerate, colour depth, etc.).

## Latex / thesis writing
### How do I lay out my thesis, and which packages are interesting to look at? 
Learning LaTeX is easier when some examples are given. This also goes for the layout and packages. For this reason there are two standard '.tex' files with all layout options. There is some documentation in the comment. One of the files (layout.tex) contains the layout options and the other one (main.tex) is an example of which packages one could use and how one could use included tex files.  
[main.tex](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/main.tex)  
[layout.tex](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/layout.tex)  
[a list](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/journals.tex) of the most common journal name abbreviations used by ADS is also included in 'main.tex'.

### Is there a simple way to run all the standard LaTeX related commands successively? 
The most straightforward way to do this is with a Makefile; all you need to do is type
`make file.dvi`  
to create the dvi file you want to produce from file.tex. Similarly you can create a .ps file by typing
`make file.ps`   
or a .pdf file,
`make file.pdf`  
This is assuming that both the Makefile listed below and your file.tex are in the same directory.

### How do I get my bibliography to look like in an astronomy paper?
In most astronomical papers, the references are given in the format 'van den Berk (2006)'. When you use plain old LaTeX, your reference will probably look like '[1]'. If you want your references to look like in real astronomy papers, you can use BibTeX. See this small [tutorial](http://www.andy-roberts.net/misc/latex/latextutorial3.html). 
Another nice property of using BibTeX is that ADS can give you BibTeX entries for all articles you want. When looking at the ADS-page of an article, just click the link named 'Bibtex entry for this abstract'. You can just copy paste the BibTeX code into your BibTeX file.
If you want to make your own style, you can try the following command:  
`latex makebst`  
you will then be asked a huge amount of questions. After answering those, a '.dbj' file will be created. To make this into a latex-usable style file use the command 
`latex filename.dbj`  
To use your style file use '\bibstyle{filename}' in your LaTeX document. 
Probably you would like to include this list of the most common journal name abbreviations used by ADS in your LaTeX document.

## IRAF
### Is there a comprehensive IRAF manual around?
First of all, IRAF is such a broad and complex system, that any comprehensive manual cannot be complete and vice versa. For this university an effort has been made to write an IRAF manual. This can be downloaded [here](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~gmulders/apifaq/manual.pdf). 
The LaTeX source code should be available at the institute. If you think that you could contribute to to it by expanding or improving, just ask the Master coordinator or one of the authors where it can be found.

# Surfspot

You can use SURFspot to obtain software for use at work; it's relatively cheap for UvA employees and students. Login with your UvAID and you should be good to go: [http://www.surfspot.nl/](http://www.surfspot.nl)

Surfspot

You can use SURFspot to obtain software for use at work; it's relatively cheap for UvA employees and students. Login with your UvAID and you should be good to go: http://www.surfspot.nl/

fields.name: ubuntu_vpn_setup
fields.text:
This method works fine on Ubuntu v9.10, but should be the same for 
any distro, with slight variations on the location of the /etc/vpnc/vpn.conf file. 

* Install "vpnc" from the Synaptic Package Manager
* Login as root and create a file /etc/vpnc/vpnc.conf
* Write and save the following in vpnc.conf:

Host=		vpn.uva.nl

GroupName = 	ipsec

GroupPwd = 	ipsec

UserName= 	<your-user>

UserPassword = 	<your-pwd>


* Run vpnc-connect as root. 
* Logout and connect as usual (e.g., "ssh -Xl user remote.science.uva.nl").

fields.name: api-rumours
fields.text:
# API Rumours

This a list of things people have heard or talk about.  
Not everything has to be true.

* Self-support is not going to happen. It is a diversion created by Martin.
* Martin does not really exist. He is a diversion created by self-support.
* The diversion does not really exist. Martin is self-support. 
* Yuri is the fastest draw in Amsterdam.
* Yuri is completely unable to lasso anything.
* API 2011 weddings:
    + Samia is married
    + Daan is married
    + Sera is married
    + Jason is married
    + Dave is married
* People are going to Paris this weekend
* What happened in Paris, stays in Paris (Confirmed - signed: Yuri, June 2011)
* This page will destroy the institute from Inside (Confirmed - signed: [Satan](http://www.pollsb.com/photos/o/2341-satan.jpg) )
* Evil (and malicious rumours) will sow the seeds of its own destruction.
* Milena is starting an online dating agency at [www.bulgariandynamite.com](http://www.bulgariandynamite.com)
* Theo will pulverize Martin's best time on 11th of November.
* Either Theo or Evert will get slapped in the face after their next race; Martin will get slapped in the face anyway.
* Every single woman in the department is pregnant. (Confirmed - signed: [Cuckoos](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Midwich_Cuckoos) )
* French people wear a scarf. (Confirmed - Gijs, Montse, Samia, Theo and Yuri)
* Yuri will go bankrupt for not asking the price of things.
* Gijs will start to wear pink suits.
* Montse stole a computer screen.
* Theo also stole a computer screen, but keeps it in his locker.
* Evert is so scared of becoming Martin that he is disguising himself as Maciej.
* There is a gold digger in the institute.
* Much sexual innuendo was made and tension came to the surface during Nathalie's leaving do. Many truths and lies were exposed. Most of them involve the rules of pool.
* Dutch translation: ghghghghghghghghghghghghhghg..... oh let me unlock.... ghghghghghghhghgghghghghghgh my bicycle ghghghghghghghghgh  ohohohohohohhohohohohohohohoho
* Samia is keeping her goal clear.
* What happens in the Thalys, stays in the Thalys, but...
   Antonia met a piano guy with LaTeX on the Thalys; he will send the LaTeX file to her Kindle.
* Someone is trying to get pregnant; it is not Samia.
* Martin has been trying to get pregnant for the last 20 years, without succes. Someone should talk to this guy, really.
* Samia actually managed to keep her goal clear for more than a period. Her team even won.
* Martin has a wedding date. Whether this is a day a wedding will take place, a person he will take to the wedding, or a piece of fruit to be eaten at a wedding remains unclear, although if the latter were to be given to the person, it would more properly be called a wedding date date date.
* Southampton is the new Groningen
* All's well that ends well.
* The British are coming.
* The lack of new rumours is a reflection on the new API work ethic.
* That means we're boring now?  That's a shame. :(
* Someone at the institute is systematically eliminating his office mates to get his own office.
* The British have (mostly) come, but ended up in Ikea.
* The landlords of Amsterdam have realized the members of API are not good tenants and have conspired to kick them all out.
fields.html:
API Rumours

This a list of things people have heard or talk about.
Not everything has to be true.

  • Self-support is not going to happen. It is a diversion created by Martin.

fields.name: bash_script
fields.text:
#Bash script to track processes

Here is a bash script that runs one or more processes and send you an email when they are done.

>\#!/bin/bash

>\# script to send simple email

>\# email subject

>SUBJECT="subject here"

>\# Email To ?

>EMAIL="id@company.com"

>\#Email test/message

>EMAILMESSAGE="emailmessage.txt"

>echo "Email message here" > $EMAILMESSAGE

>/Applications/rsi/idl_6.3/bin/idl grtrans_wrapper >& out.log

>\# send an email using /bin/mail or /usr/bin/mail

>/usr/bin/mail -s "$SUBJECT" "$EMAIL" < $EMAILMESSAGE
fields.html:
Bash script to track processes

Here is a bash script that runs one or more processes and send you an email when they are done.

#!/bin/bash

# script to send simple email

# email subject

SUBJECT="subject here"

# Email To ?

EMAIL="id@company.com"

#Email test/message

EMAILMESSAGE="emailmessage.txt"

echo "Email message here" > $EMAILMESSAGE

/Applications/rsi/idl_6.3/bin/idl grtrans_wrapper >& out.log

# send an email using /bin/mail or /usr/bin/mail

/usr/bin/mail -s "$SUBJECT" "$EMAIL" < $EMAILMESSAGE

fields.name: coffee_codes
fields.text:
# Coffee codes

The new coffee machines (the one by the elevator and the one in the corridor away from the common room) have a "snelkeuze" option, in which you can bypass the individual options and punch in a four-digit code. Listed below in ascending order are some codes for drinks favoured by APIs. Feel free to add your own. *Update* Unfathomably, the codes are different for different machines. Sorry. *Update 2* So just list them in order of machine:
###API
###Lift
###Physics
That shouldn't be too hard to do and understand, right?

*Update 3* There are only two sets of codes: big machine and small machine. But now the big machine has been taken away...

0004    --      bonnen koffie, zwart sterkte 5/5 on the big machine

0004    --      Espresso, zwart in the small machine near the physics department

0007    --      Almost same as below but restricted to people with license to kill.


0017    --      Bonenkoffie, melk

0032    --      Bonenkoffie, suiker 1/5

0030    --      Bonenkoffie, suiker 1/5 (machine by common room)

0057    --      Bonenkoffie, melk, suiker 1/5 (machine by the common   room)

0067    --      Bonenkoffie, melk, suiker 1/5

0222    --      Espresso, melk

0373    --      Cappuccino, sterkte 4/5, suiker 2/5

0456    --      verse blad thee, zwart, sterkte 4/5

0457    --      verse blad thee, zwart, sterkte 5/5

0461    --      verse blad thee (yeah right), strength 4/5, sugar 1/5

0666    --      Red hot drinks from Hell.

fields.name: for_newcomers
fields.text:
#Welcome to the Anton Pannekoek Institute (API)!

Here is a short overview of useful information and links to other pages describing the institute, how to set up your computer, and advice on getting settled in Amsterdam.

##Passwords
First of all, there are three kinds of username/password combinations:

* Your UvANetID: used to connect to the wireless internet (see below), log in to the employers part of the [UvA website](http://www.english.uva.nl/start.cfm) (click on "Information for: Staff") and [WebMail](http://webmail.uva.nl/).  
* Science account: used to log in to the Unix cluster and connect the VPN client.  
* Internal web site: used exclusively to log in to [the internal part](http://www.astro.uva.nl/internal/) of [the institute site](http://www.astro.uva.nl).

##Wireless
[General information](http://www.ic.uva.nl/ic/draadloos-internet/general-information.cfm) and [manuals](http://www.ic.uva.nl/ic/draadloos-internet/handleidingen.cfm) for setting up the wireless internet connection for the different platforms can be found on the UvA web site. Since they are all in Dutch, there is a description for [Macs](mac_os_x-wireless-setup) on the wiki. Until you get a hardwired connection at your desk it's best to use the Eduroam wifi, for which hopefully you have an account from your previous university.

##Events
A list of common events at the API: [regular events](regular_events)
:    The current schedule: [agenda](/internal/agenda)

##Housing
Ask the secretaries for help if you are from abroad and need housing. More information can be found [here](http://www.uva.nl/en/research/phd/practical-matters).

##FAQ
A list of frequently asked (computer) questions: [FAQ](api-faq)
:    And just browse this wiki and ask your office mates!


##Settling in to Life at API
The people who work at API are frequently referred to as 'APIs'. This place is a lot like a family.

**Meeting with HR:** The necessary first step. Here you sign the contract, get your UvAnet ID, and get lots of important information and papers. 

**Getting your employee badge:** After your meeting with HR, you will want to get your employee badge. This is used to get you to the elevator on the main floor, lock/unlock office doors in the API, and most importantly, get coffee from the giant coffee udders near the washrooms. You'll need to go to [this website](https://www.mijnuvapas.nl/site/) (the UK flag at the bottom switches the page to English) and follow the instructions to upload a passport-style photo of yourself. It's usually ready in 2-3 days after that (you should get an email). Go down to the main desk and pick it up, use the machine next to
the desk to activate it for the coffee machines, come up to API, talk to the secretariat and ask them to put in the request to activate your badge for all the office doors, and then go back down to the main desk and they'll activate your badge for all the doors in API. Now your employee badge should be fully functional!

**Expatcenter (for non-EU citizens):** After meeting with HR you'll usually have a meeting with the Expatcenter to get your residence permit (if you're not an EU citizen). **If you want to bank with ABN-AMRO** (many folks do), **call the World Trade Center office in advance and ask for an appointment after your Expatcenter meeting, since they're in the same building.** Allot about an hour for your Expatcenter meeting. It will save you an extra trip to Zuid, which is about 45 minutes by public transit from Science Park. Also, at the end of your Expatcenter meeting you will get a goodie bag with tips and tidbits and fun things. **Included in this bag is a (free) prepaid 15 euro sim card from Lebara**, which if you stick into an old unlocked phone can function as your temporary mobile until you have a proper Dutch bank account and residence permit. Some of us hold onto an old phone and this sim card to lend to our friends and family to contact us while they're here visiting. Also, you will need to return to the Expatcenter with your original birth certificate with an 'apostille' (a shiny official fancy sticker) so that they can make an official copy for their records, so email your family now and ask them to safely mail it to you here.

**Lunch at the API:** Some APIs bring a lunch from home and some APIs buy it from the canteen on the main floor of the building. There are some microwaves to heat up your food in the canteen. To purchase lunch, you will need a Dutch debit card, which typically won't arrive until a week or two after you have your first appointment at the bank. In the mean time, you are able to go to the front desk on the main floor with 20 euros cash (that is the only increment, as far as we know) and ask them for a **'chip card'**. This you can use to purchase food and use the vending machines at the canteen.

**Going out:** We've compiled a [restaurant page](restaurant_recommendations), listed by approximate neighbourhood.

##Anything else?
And since this is work in progress, feel free to post questions here, that you would like to have had answered when you arrived. Just click the edit button below and type it in, and then tell someone so that we know to look here to answer the questions. Asking questions not only helps you but also those who come after you!

**Questions:**

**Which mobile phone companies are the best?**
:    People tend to go with [T-mobile](http://www.t-mobile.nl/home) or [Vodafone](https://www.vodafone.nl/). You need a Dutch bank account (and residence permit, if applicable) before most places will let you have a subscription/contract mobile plan.

**What is a good supermarket and drugstore?**
:    *Albert Heijn* and *Jumbo* are grocery store chains. If you'll frequently shop at Albert Heijn we recommend getting a "bonuskaart" (ask the cashier). This will help you save money! *Etos* and *Kruidvat* are common drugstores where you can buy shampoo, soap, bandaids/plasters, etc. We recommend you go to your local bakery (bakkerij) to get bread, and your neighbourhood fruit and vegetable stand (groenteboer) to get good-quality fresh produce.

**I really miss ___ food from my home country! Where can I find it?**
:    There are a number of international food stores in Amsterdam. Ask around! Abbie's favourite for North American and basic East Asian food is [Tijn's International Food Store](http://www.yelp.com/biz/tijns-toko-amsterdam).

**Where can I go to get sheets/towels/dishes/lightbulbs/kitchen appliances/etc?**
:    [*HEMA*](http://www.hema.nl/): Clothing, raincoats and rainpants, umbrellas, dishes, home linens (sheets, towels, curtains), office supplies, bike panniers/saddle bags, wine, sweets, cute boxes to store things in, simple home decor, etc. It's a bit like the store Target in North America, but without the hardware-type things.
:    [*Blokker*](http://www.blokker.nl): Brooms, mops, buckets, kitchen and home appliances, organisational tools, kitchen supplies, trashcans, etc. Like the store Bed Bath & Beyond in North America minus the 'bed' part, or like Linens 'N Things minus the 'linens' part.
:    [*Ikea*](http://www.ikea.com/): Pretty much everything you need to furnish an apartment completely. Accessible via the metro at Bullewijk station.
:    [*Praxis*](http://www.praxis.nl/): Hardware store (like Home Depot, Lowes, or Totem in North America) with lightbulbs, step stools, power tools, and hardcore home renovation-type things like doors and windows.
:    [*Xenos*](http://www.xenos.nl/): Home organisation things, seasonal decorations, vases, candles, craft supplies, kitchen supplies, and knicknacks.

**How late are stores open?**
:    Check out [http://www.opentot.nl/](http://www.opentot.nl/). Albert Heijn is open until about 22:00 most days, Etos tends to close at 18:00, Ikea closes at 21:00 on weekdays and Saturday. Places *are* open on Sundays but have limited hours.

**How do I file an expense report?**
:    Talk to [Lide](http://www.astro.uva.nl/people/lidewijde-stolte/)! The 'self-service portal' is [here](https://zelfbediening.uva.nl/irj/portal). Generally they prefer for you to wait until you have a few items and then file one expense report for all of them.

fields.name: ubuntu_wireless_setup
fields.text:
# Setting up the wireless under Ubuntu

If you're persistent it is possible to find instructions on this somewhere in the maze that is the UvA website, but they are either outdated or plain wrong. What does work is the following (tested under various versions of Ubuntu, may also work on other linux distributions)

In the wireless networks GUI, choose the 'eduroam' network, then fill in the following options:

Wireless security:    | WPA & WPA2  
Authentication:       | Tunneled TLS  
Anonymous identity:   | anonymous@uva.nl  
CA certificate:       | None  
Inner authentication: | PAP  
Username:             | <your uvanet ID>  
Password:             | <your uvanet password>

You will be prompted whether you're sure you want to connect without a certificate, just choose yes. This is the crucial difference with the official UvA instructions, which provide a certificate that doesn't work.

fields.name: guest-wireless
fields.text:
# Wireless account for guests

If you have a guest (or more), it's easy to set up wireless access for them. Go to [https://guests.ic.uva.nl/](https://guests.ic.uva.nl/), log in with your UvAnetID, and create a single guest user account. 

It may be good to use your email address instead of theirs, so that the login details will be sent to someone who actually has internet access (the details will also be shown on the page itself, so the email is a backup). 

Take care of the time stamps and time zone settings (maximum allowed is 3 weeks before you need to create a new one), but otherwise, you should have a guest wireless account within 15 minutes or so.
fields.html:
Wireless account for guests

Take care of the time stamps and time zone settings (maximum allowed is 3 weeks before you need to create a new one), but otherwise, you should have a guest wireless account within 15 minutes or so.

fields.name: phd_graduation
fields.text:
#PhD graduation

The FNWI contact person for the promotion procedure is Meike Scholten, you can contact her for all your questions about the procedure and since she is keeping track of all FNWI PhD-students, she would like to meet you in person. 
She's working on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday morning.

Meike Scholten,
M.A.Scholten@uva.nl
Tel: 7992
Room C2.140

*This is a quest in progress, more information will come as I obtain them.*

A good place to start your promotion procedure is the UvA web page ['Procedure for obtaining a PhD at the UvA'](http://www.uva.nl/en/research/phd/procedure/procedure-for-obtaining-a-phd/procedure-for-obtaining-a-phd.html). There you will find all the forms you need to fill in and send back and forth to the administration.

Two (if you have a Dutch education) or three (if you do not have a Dutch education) forms have to be filled in in this **exact sequence**:

* Request for exemption from the educational requirement (for non-Dutch education)
* Request for admission for a Doctorate at the University of Amsterdam
* Proposal for establishment of the Doctorate Committee

##Request for exemption from the educational requirement
This form is only asked if you have a **non-Dutch** education.

**This step should be done *before* or *immediately after* you begin your PhD.**

To find out if you already have the exemption, you can send an email to [Mrs Boeren](mailto:h.m.f.boeren@uva.nl) from the College voor Promoties/Doctorate Board. There they can look into your personal file and check whether you have the required documents (Bachelor and Master diploma) or not.

* If you have the required documents, you will have an appointment to show them the original copies and give them the [Appendix 9 form](http://www.uva.nl/binaries/content/assets/uva/nl/onderzoek/promoveren/procedure/appendix-9-exemption-and-checklist.doc).
* If you don't have the required documents, you will be asked to provide them as well as the [Appendix 9 form](http://www.uva.nl/binaries/content/assets/uva/nl/onderzoek/promoveren/procedure/appendix-9-exemption-and-checklist.doc). *Depending which country you come from, you might need to provide a official translation too.*

Once you have the exemption proof, proceed to *Request for admission for a Doctorate at the UvA*.

##Request for admission for a Doctorate at the University of Amsterdam
**This step should be done *immediately after* the start of the PhD.**

All you need for this step is to fill in [Appendix 7 form](http://www.uva.nl/binaries/content/assets/uva/nl/onderzoek/promoveren/admission-request-form-01092012.doc) with your personal information, your promoter and co-promoter (or supervisor) details. Once you have it signed by everyone, the form should be sent/given to the Dean's office.

##Proposal for establishment of the Doctorate Committee
**This step should be done about *6 months* before the desired graduation date.**

The [Proposal for establishment of the Doctorate Committee](http://www.uva.nl/binaries/content/assets/uva/en/research/phd/doctorate-committee-request-form-01092012.doc) is the last form that needs to be sent to the Dean's office. Once you have filled in  all the names and titles of your committee members, you should send/give the form to the Dean's office.

##Arrange provisional graduation date
Now that the doctoral committee has been approved, the doctoral candidate is allowed to contact the Beadle’s Office (Bureau Pedel) for a preliminary doctoral thesis defence date. Before doing so, the candidate can consult the timetable of the Agnietenkapel or de Aula (in case that more than 90 guests are expected) to check which dates are still available. The timetable can be found on [Promotie planning](http://www.uva.nl/promotieplanning):

* Close the initial splash screen by clicking on the button "Sluiten";
* click on "English" on the upper right for convenience;
* click on "Location view"/"Locatieweergave" on the upper right;
* click on "Add Location timetable"/"Locatierooster toevoegen";
* click on "Agnietenkapel 1.03 (Promotiezaal) (90)" or "Aula - Lutherse Kerk 0.00 (405)" and "Add Location timetable"/"Locatierooster toevoegen" below;
* if in the week or day view it says "Beschikbaar voor promotie" that time is still available.

The **Beadle’s Office** can be reached by phone on **020-525 2808** or by email **BureauPedel@uva.nl**. After the Beadle’s Office has offered a few available dates, the candidate can consult the committee members to agree on a suitable date.

fields.name: ubuntu_printing
fields.text:
# Printing on Ubuntu

To install, say, printer p005204 on Ubuntu (I tried it on v10.04, but should work for any other version too) do the following:

System --> Administration --> Printing

Select the button "Add" --> Network Printer --> LPD/LPR Host or Printer

In "Host" type "stafflp.science.uva.nl" 
In "Queue" type "p005204"
Press "Forward"

Now select the driver:
"Generic" --> "Postscript Printer" --> "Generic Postscript Printer (recommended)"

Now go to print, waste some paper and give your contribution to destroy the Amazon.

fields.name: api-meerkamp
fields.text:
# API Meerkamp  

Our institute has a long tradition in sports of all kinds, including a
highly successful soccer team, an annual squash tournament, ice skating
outings, long distance running, etc, etc. The API participants are
always extremely fanatic. They are fighting each other almost to death
for the glory to be the best of our institute. Because different sports
are always hard to compare, this leads to the question who is the most
allround API sportsman or woman of the year. To solve this question for
once and for all, several years ago a concept was introduced: "the
annual API-meerkamp". (Meerkamp is a hard word to translate, but it
means something like multi-discipline competition.) We are bringing this
API tradition back to life and these are the rules.

1. The schedule is not fixed. Every API member can organize as many
events as he/she likes.  
2. An event is defined as a sport, or game, for which at the end of the
event the participants are ranked from first to last.
3. There must be at least seven members from our institute participating
in the event. If not, the points do not count for the API-meerkamp.
4. Everyone should be able to participate in the events. This means that
the required material (rackets, skates, etc.) should be provided by the
organizers, or be available at the site of the event.
5. The event must be announced, well in advance, to the whole institute.
6. The rules of the game must be completely clear before it starts.
7. The winner of the event will get the number of participants plus 2
points. The number 2 will get one point less than the winner, the number
3 will get two points less than the winner, etc. This means that the one
ending last will always get 3 points. You don't get points for the
events in which you didn't participate. The considerations for chosing
this system are that:
    1. The most popular events at the API are also the most important events for the API-meerkamp.
    2. Every participant will get points, so ending last or one but last makes a difference.
    3. Ending last is always better than skipping an event.
8. At the end of the season (the Christmas party), the points of each
participant per event are added. The one with highest total points will
be the API all-round champion of the year.

What makes the API-meerkamp special is that there is no fixed schedule.
Everyone can add their own favorite games or sports. Therefore the
meerkamp could include a very broad range of events, from a real sports
like squash, darts, pool, swimming, skating, running, table tennis, to
something virtual like the computer game Quake. Or even some events
like card games. For every event the participants can score points and
at the end of the season we know who is the best.

One thing is for sure: to become the API all-round champion
of the year, you'll have to cross your limits and compete in things
you've never done before!

The API-meerkamp can only be a true success when many different events
are organized. In the end, the most important thing is to have fun! The
options are unlimited, so we are sure the API meerkamp will be a great
success!

## Tournaments:

------------- | ------------- | ------------- | ------------- | ---------------

## Original email (sent April 2, 2012)

Hello everyone-

Because we have such a lovely giant chess board downstairs it seems inevitable that we have a chess tournament as part of our meerkamp!  Details for all interested parties-

1) The tournament will be organized in what's called a Swiss-system tournament, which for those too lazy to look it up on Wikipedia means everyone who enters the tournament will play four games.  Because we have all year to do this and we all lead busy lives, you'll have a month to figure out with your opponent when you want to play and tell me the result before I organize the next round (we can take a break in midsummer if it sounds like too many people will be out).  Spectators are permitted, but are not allowed to interfere in the game itself (ie offer help etc) unless it's to point out an irregularity.

2) The first round will be randomly assigned, and if you win your match you get 1 point, losing gives you 0 points, and a draw/stalemate gives you a half point.  After the first round winners will play winners, losers will play losers, etc, and in subsequent matches players will play another player with the same or similar score (so by the 4th game if you won two prior games you'll be matched with someone else who's also won two).  Effort is made so that everyone plays black twice and white twice, and that you only play against a certain person once.

3) If we have fewer than 16 players there is a chance that we don't have a clear victor (because two people could in practice win all their games and never play against each other), and in this event we'll have a final knockout game to choose the victor.  Everyone else will be ranked based on how many games they've won and the skill of the people they've played- you usually don't get ties under this system, but one or two people might have to play a tiebreaker match.

4) In case any disagreements break out over the rules of the game, we will defer to the [official Laws of Chess](http://www.fide.com/component/handbook/?id=124&view=article) set forth by the World Chess Federation (In other news, chess isn't played by rules but by laws!) You're welcome to record your game or play by the clock if you so desire, but it's not required.

5) If you're interested in participating, sign up here ASAP- http://www.astro.uva.nl/internal/wiki/view/meerkamp-chess/ and I will organize the first round sometime after Easter.  In the future this page will also be used to list the upcoming matches and past scores so everyone can keep track of things.

Best of luck to all participants!
-Yvette

PS- Because a chess set can also be used to play checkers/draughts quite easily we should also consider organizing that... I'm using a royal "we" here in hopes that someone else will volunteer to set it up though!

fields.name: meerkamp-nescioloop
fields.text:
# API meerkamp - Running

Dear APIs,

I present to you the first event of the API meerkamp: the Nescioloop. 

This is a running race over 7.5 or 15 km, which goes right through science park, and as such is the ideal running race to include in the API meerkamp. It will take place on April 15th. I know that's already in two weeks time, but most of you weren't going to train for it more than one or two times anyway, and there's plenty of time for that.

Most people will probably want to do the 7.5 km, but anyone wishing to run the 15 km will for purposes of the API meerkamp have their time normalized to a 7.5 km time, using the ratio between the world records over 5 and 10 km. (so if the world record over 10 km is 2.1 times that over 5 km, your 15km time will be divided by 2.1 to create a 7.5 km time - I'm using 5 and 10 km times for this because both have strong world records set in equal circumstances).

It has been suggested to me to do the same normalization for women and men. Personally I don't really care either way, so if anyone has any strong opinions on this please let me know. I'll inform participants of a definitive ruling on this before the race.

For more information on the details of the race, see www.nescioloop.nl.

Cheers,
Thijs

Meerkamp Main Wiki Page: [api-meerkamp](api-meerkamp)

# API meerkamp - ping pong tournament

As already pre-announced, we're organizing another event for the API Meerkamp: the API ping pong tournament! This sporting event will take place coming Wednesday, 9 May, starting at 5pm and we aim at finishing around 8pm. We will set up two tables in the colloquium room C4.174. We'd like to encourage everyone, whether you're a ping pong novice, a recreative camping player, or a table tennis guru, to sign up, which you can do here. Please sign up on Tuesday 8 May at the latest, so we have enough time to put together a schedule for the tournament.
Looking forward to lots of ping pong fun!

fields.name: meerkamp-eurocup
fields.text:
# API meerkamp - Eurocup 2012

Hi Pannekoeker,

Another Api Meerkamp event for you to participate in.

As you might or might not know, the European Championship Soccer 2012
will start on Friday, June 8th in Poland/Ukraine.

We think that this is a good opportunity for all Pannekoekers to demonstrate their knowledge of soccer, and organize therefore a "Pannekoek-Soccer-Pool". We invite everybody at the Institute to join this competition; participation is just for fun, there is no fee to be paid, and there are therefore no prizes to be won either.
The competitor who is able to make the best prediction of the 24 games, which will be played in the 1st round, and the top-four of the tournament after the final on the first of July will be crowned the "Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012".

Note that we include the 1st round only, since it is too complicated to make predictions for the following rounds. Nevertheless, the end result of the soccer-pool will only be known after the last whistle has been blown in the stadium in Kiev on the first of July!

The rules under which the competition will be held are the following:

    1) Predict the result of each of the 24 matches in the 1st round,
       and give the names of the countries with ranking 1 to 4 after
       the final on the first of July.
    2) You earn points when you predict:
       a) the exact result                              4 points
       b) the correct 'Toto' result, i.e. win/draw/loss 2 points
       c) the number of goals scored by one of the      1 point
          countries, but not predicting the exact
          result
       d) combination of b) and c)                      3 points
       e) predicting a country surviving                2 points
          the Quarter Finals.
       f) predicting a country surviving                3 points
          the Semi Finals.
       g) predicting the 3rd or 4th place               4 points
          there is no match for place 3 or 4
       h) predicting the European Champion 2012         7 points
                         2nd place                      3 points

We will post an update of the ranking of the Pool-competitors every day during the 1st round, so you can immediately see how good/bad you and the others did!

The one who is leading the competition is wearing an orange t-shirt
provide by the organisation to show how good she/he is.
Every day this could be someone else. The person has to be at API to wear it.

As an example for the scoring, a fictive result:

    The result of Match 18 Griekenland vs Rusland is 3 - 2.
    If you predicted 3 - 2 you will earn 4 points (Exact result)
                     4 - 1               2        (Griekenland won)
                     4 - 2               3        (Griekenland won,
                                                   Rusland scored 2 goals)
                     1 - 2               1 point  (Rusland scored 2 goals)
                     1 - 1               0        (Totally wrong)

Note: In predicting the correct top-four of the tournament you can gain one third of the maximum number of points which can be won in the 1st round (to be exact: 96 and 32). So, even when you are not familiar with the ins and outs of modern soccer and mess up in predicting the results of the 24 matches, it is still possible to gain immortality by becoming the Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012!

Join the Pannekoek-Soccer-Pool and fill in the scheme at the end of this message. Join in even when you are not in the country during part of the tournament for reasons of vacation, observing-run, summer school or other obligations; the more competitors the more fun!

Send the scheme by E-Mail to Martin (M.H.M.Heemskerk@uva.nl) before June 8th, and we will know by July 1 who is the Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012!

***** 1ST ROUND SCHEDULE (cut here) *****

    Match  1:   Polen        -  Griekenland :      -
    Match  2:   Rusland      -  Tsjechie    :      -
    Match  3:   Nederland    -  Denemarken  :      -

fields.html:
API meerkamp - Eurocup 2012

Hi Pannekoeker,

Another Api Meerkamp event for you to participate in.

As you might or might not know, the European Championship Soccer 2012 will start on Friday, June 8th in Poland/Ukraine.

We think that this is a good opportunity for all Pannekoekers to demonstrate their knowledge of soccer, and organize therefore a "Pannekoek-Soccer-Pool". We invite everybody at the Institute to join this competition; participation is just for fun, there is no fee to be paid, and there are therefore no prizes to be won either. The competitor who is able to make the best prediction of the 24 games, which will be played in the 1st round, and the top-four of the tournament after the final on the first of July will be crowned the "Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012".

Note that we include the 1st round only, since it is too complicated to make predictions for the following rounds. Nevertheless, the end result of the soccer-pool will only be known after the last whistle has been blown in the stadium in Kiev on the first of July!

The rules under which the competition will be held are the following:

1) Predict the result of each of the 24 matches in the 1st round,
   and give the names of the countries with ranking 1 to 4 after
   the final on the first of July.
2) You earn points when you predict:
   a) the exact result                              4 points
   b) the correct 'Toto' result, i.e. win/draw/loss 2 points
   c) the number of goals scored by one of the      1 point
      countries, but not predicting the exact
      result
   d) combination of b) and c)                      3 points
   e) predicting a country surviving                2 points
      the Quarter Finals.
   f) predicting a country surviving                3 points
      the Semi Finals.
   g) predicting the 3rd or 4th place               4 points
      there is no match for place 3 or 4
   h) predicting the European Champion 2012         7 points
                     2nd place                      3 points

We will post an update of the ranking of the Pool-competitors every day during the 1st round, so you can immediately see how good/bad you and the others did!

The one who is leading the competition is wearing an orange t-shirt provide by the organisation to show how good she/he is. Every day this could be someone else. The person has to be at API to wear it.

As an example for the scoring, a fictive result:

The result of Match 18 Griekenland vs Rusland is 3 - 2.
If you predicted 3 - 2 you will earn 4 points (Exact result)
                 4 - 1               2        (Griekenland won)
                 4 - 2               3        (Griekenland won,
                                               Rusland scored 2 goals)
                 1 - 2               1 point  (Rusland scored 2 goals)
                 1 - 1               0        (Totally wrong)

Note: In predicting the correct top-four of the tournament you can gain one third of the maximum number of points which can be won in the 1st round (to be exact: 96 and 32). So, even when you are not familiar with the ins and outs of modern soccer and mess up in predicting the results of the 24 matches, it is still possible to gain immortality by becoming the Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012!

Join the Pannekoek-Soccer-Pool and fill in the scheme at the end of this message. Join in even when you are not in the country during part of the tournament for reasons of vacation, observing-run, summer school or other obligations; the more competitors the more fun!

Send the scheme by E-Mail to Martin (M.H.M.Heemskerk@uva.nl) before June 8th, and we will know by July 1 who is the Pannekoek-Soccer-Wizard 2012!

fields.name: meerkamp-karting
fields.text:
# Api Meerkamp - Karting

Dear APIs,

The principle of karting is very simple.
Everybody drives his own kart around as fast as he can.
Each time you cross the finish line, your time is registered.
Make as many laps as you can, as fast as you can in 12 minutes.
This is the duration of the race.
At the end of the race you get a piece of paper with all your lap times.
The fastest lap you make will count for the meerkamp.

For more information on the details of the race, see http://www.raceplanet.com/karting/amsterdam/613

Cheers,
Dario

## Other users and remote execution
When running a program on these machines, keep in mind that someone might want to work on that system as well. Check if the computer is being used, e.g. using top and be nice with your program! (see how to be nice on the [remote execution](remote-execution) page.) You could also ofcourse put a paper on the computer, saying that you are running a program on it and to contact you if the pc is needed, and that it should not be turned off.

# API Wiki main page

## Purpose

The API wiki serves to collect practical information about things at the API, whether technical, administrative, social or otherwise. You can put things like FAQs here, or have a progress page on the latest happenings regarding e.g. an upcoming or current event. 

## Content
` ` | Categories     | ` ` 
-   | -------------- |  -
    ||
    | [Administrative & Procedures](administration) | 
    | [Journals & online data](journals_data) |
    | [ICT & Software](ict_software) | 
    | [Tips for newcomers](for_newcomers) |
    | [Entertainment & Social](entertainment) |    
    ||
    | [List of all pages](/internal/wiki/all/) | 



## Sensitive information
These wiki pages are editable only by API people, but accessible, and thus readable, by all API people. Information about, for example, a research group, that is sensitive, shouldn't be on this wiki.

## Adding/Modifying a wiki page
Information on how you can contribute to the API wiki site
is given on the [wiki-editing](wiki) page.


## Newcomers
Students or employees that are new to the institute might want to start with the [tips for newcomers](for_newcomers).

fields.name: wiki
fields.text:
# Wiki

## Creating a new page

Use the ["create a new page"](/internal/wiki/create/) link on the left. A page name can consist of numbers and letters, underscores and dashes; the difference between upper- and lowercase is ignored. There is no explicit wiki naming necessity or convention like CapitalizedWords.

You can create or use existing *category* pages to groups things and keep a set of pages together.

## Edit a page

Click on the blue "Edit page" link to edit a page. The editing box appears below the preview box on the actual editing page; the preview gets updated once you've pressed "Save".

This wiki uses markdown with a few extensions (for e.g. tables) for layout. See the ["help on editing"](help-editing-wikipage) page for more information.

## Page history

There is *no* page history or undo function. If you remove text and then save the edited page, or delete a page, you cannot undo that. You can always make a copy of the old text in a simple text file, to be on the safe side.

fields.name: midas
fields.text:
#MIDAS
## getting MIDAS
MIDAS is a free data reduction package provided by ESO. It can be downloaded [here](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/). PyMIDAS is also linked there.


## Documentation
There is little documentation about MIDAS besides the manual from ESO.
[Volume A](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/doc/user/98NOV/vola/index.html) and [Volume B](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/doc/user/98NOV/volb/index.html). (or in postscript format: [Vol A](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/doc/user/98NOV/vol1.ps.gz) and [Vol B](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/doc/user/98NOV/vol2.ps.gz)).

And there is this FAQ: [Everything you always wanted to know about MIDAS](http://www.eso.org/sci/software/esomidas/doc/everything.html). The title is a lie, you want to know more than what is in there, but it's a decent start. 

The in-program help function is in most cases sufficient to get your commands to work. However, finding the right command can be tricky. 
The Help function can be accessed through the command line using
 
>*'HELP' or 
>*'HELP command/subcommand'

And commands do not have to be written in full, as long as it is long enough to have only a single possible interpretation.
For example: 'HELP SET/GRAPH' can be accessed by typing 'h se/gr'


## MIDAS programs
I recommend using the MIDAS scripting language. It is easy to write and very little extra work even if you use the command only once. 

Just write the commando's in a text file, one command per line, and save it as a .prg in /midwork. Then you can call the program from the midas prompt using: '@@ filename par1 par2 par3 ... par 8', where par1 through par8 are optional parameters. 

## For loops
You can create FOR loops in MIDAS, using the GOTO statement and it would look something like this:

    DEFINE/LOCAL j/i/1/1 0
    LOOP:
    j = j+1
    <<some commands here>>
    IF j .LT. 35 GOTO LOOP

## Quirks and other things to keep in mind
* When copying an image to postscript, keep in mind that it will be printed for the size of an A4 ps file. Resizing the image in MIDAS itself does not change the output (much). Things like textsize do change ofcourse.
* You can execute shell commands from MIDAS by adding a $ in front. e.g. to list files type: $ls
* Using the above trick you can incorporate other programs, like awk, into your MIDAS script and run everything you need with a single command.


## Sample program
This is a program I've written that would show me the spectrum of some normalised spectra by typing:

    @@ showspec 4000 4250 0.6 1.15

if saved as [showspec.prg](http://www.atdv.nl/midas/showspec.prg)

fields.name: windows_installation_latex
fields.text:
# LaTeX for Windows

## MiKTeX
To install LaTeX for windows you need MiKTeX [http://miktex.org](http://miktex.org). Download the latest version (2.9 at the time of this writing). You can choose between:
* a basic installer (~160 Mb) which includes most packages.
* a net installer (~7Mb) which downloads the packages you need. 

There are also experimental 64 bit versions available of the above versions. 

I recommend the basic installer, then you will not need an internet connection while compiling in case you don't have the required package yet. 

## Editors
There are many editors available, Wikipedia has a list with dedicated LaTeX editors, however, you can use any text editor you like. The benefit of these dedicated editors is that they also compile your document for you. See for the full list: [Wikipedia list of LaTeX editors Linux, Windows&Mac](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_TeX_editors). 

Two decent editors for windows are:

* [WinEDT](http://www.winedt.com/) is a commercial editor provided for by the UvA on windows machines. 
* [TexnicCenter](http://www.texniccenter.org/) is a good free LaTeX editor for Windows.

Also if you like Kile very much, you can get it for windows as well:[Kile on windows](http://sourceforge.net/apps/mediawiki/kile/index.php?title=KileOnWindows)

fields.name: bibtex
fields.text:
#BiBTeX


## Usage
###The commands for BiBTeX in your preamble:

    \usepackage{natbib}                    
    \bibpunct{(}{)}{;}{a}{}{,}               
    \bibliographystyle{chicagoa}            

The first command includes the natbib package. 
The second command defines where what brackets and or punctuation is needed see also:[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib](http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib).
The third command lets you select a bibliography style. 


###The commands in your text:

Command                 | Output
----------------------  | ----------------------------
\citet{goossens93}	|Goossens et al. (1993)
\citep{goossens93}	|(Goossens et al., 1993)
\citet*{goossens93}	|Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin (1993)
\citep*{goossens93}	|(Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin, 1993)
\citeauthor{goossens93}	|Goossens et al.
\citeauthor*{goossens93}|	Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin
\citeyear{goossens93}	|1993
\citeyearpar{goossens93}|	(1993)
\citealt{goossens93}	|Goossens et al. 1993
\citealp{goossens93}	|Goossens et al., 1993

Where the 'goossens93' can be anything you choose, however first author combined with the last 2 digits of the year is common.  

See also: [http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib](http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib)

### Sample Bibliography entry

    @article{greenwade93,
    author  = "George D. Greenwade",
    title   = "The {C}omprehensive {T}ex {A}rchive {N}etwork ({CTAN})",
    year    = "1993",
    journal = "TUGBoat",
    volume  = "14",
    number  = "3",
    pages   = "342--351"
    }

fields.html:
BiBTeX

Usage

The commands for BiBTeX in your preamble:

\usepackage{natbib}                    
\bibpunct{(}{)}{;}{a}{}{,}               
\bibliographystyle{chicagoa}

The first command includes the natbib package. The second command defines where what brackets and or punctuation is needed see also:http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib. The third command lets you select a bibliography style.

The commands in your text:

Command Output
citet{goossens93} Goossens et al. (1993)
citep{goossens93} (Goossens et al., 1993)
citet*{goossens93} Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin (1993)
citep*{goossens93} (Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin, 1993)
citeauthor{goossens93} Goossens et al.
citeauthor*{goossens93} Goossens, Mittlebach, and Samarin
citeyear{goossens93} 1993
citeyearpar{goossens93} (1993)
citealt{goossens93} Goossens et al. 1993
citealp{goossens93} Goossens et al., 1993

Where the 'goossens93' can be anything you choose, however first author combined with the last 2 digits of the year is common.

See also: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Bibliography_Management#Natbib

Sample Bibliography entry

@article{greenwade93,
author  = "George D. Greenwade",
title   = "The {C}omprehensive {T}ex {A}rchive {N}etwork ({CTAN})",
year    = "1993",
journal = "TUGBoat",
volume  = "14",
number  = "3",
pages   = "342--351"
}

The NASA adsabs provides BiBTeX entries fore asy copy/paste. Just keep in mind to change the @ARTICLE{2011AN....332..232K line to something easier to remember.

\bibliography{bibtexentries}

for a bibtex file called 'bibtexentries.bib'

fields.name: adsabs
fields.text:
# SAO/NASA Astrophysics Data System

## Links
* [ADS Labs](http://adslabs.org): This is v2.0, give it a spin! 
* [ADSABS Classic](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abstract_service.html): Ye olde ADS. 



## Tips & Tricks

* Starting the author query with an `^` makes it look for first author only.


## MyADS [login](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-manage_account?man_cmd=login) or [sign up](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-manage_account?man_cmd=new)
You can sign up on ADS and receive benefits. With ADS Labs it should also keep a record of your search history and gives you a list of articles that you are likely interested in. 

With MyADS you can also signup for a weekly mail with papers about topics of your interest. 

## Private Library
It is possible to store articles in a private library. This is usefull to keep your bibliography list together, and if you are working in a group everyone can see this library (with the link) however, only the owner can add or remove articles from this.

fields.text:
# Journals & Online Data Services
## Online Journals & Papers

* [ADS Abstract](adsabs)
* [arXiv: Astro-ph](http://arxiv.org/archive/astro-ph/)

### Missing Articles
* If you [cannot access a specific article](journal_access) list it here.


## Online Data Services
* [SIMBAD (strasbourg)](http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/): Astronomical object database.
* [SIMBAD (harvard-mirror)](http://simbak.cfa.harvard.edu/simbad/): Astronomical object database.
* [VizieR (strasbourg)](http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR): Astronomical Catalogues.
* [VizieR (harvard-mirror)](http://vizier.cfa.harvard.edu/viz-bin/VizieR/): Astronomical Catalogues.
* [DIB catalog](http://leonid.arc.nasa.gov/DIBcatalog.html): Diffuse Interstellar Band catalog by Jenniskens et al.
* [NIST Atomic Spectra Database](http://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/ASD/lines_form.html).

Note that the strasbourg databases are sometimes slow, try the harvard ones in that case. 

## Science Archives
* [ESO Science archive](http://archive.eso.org/cms/eso-data): La Silla, VLT(i)/Paranal, APEX.
* [ESA science archive](http://www.sciops.esa.int/index.php?project=SAT&index.php): XMM, HST, INTEGRAL, HERSCHEL, PLANCK and more.
* [NASA Data centers & Archives](http://cxc.harvard.edu/cdo/observatory_links.html#NASA): Chandra, HEASARC, MAST, etc.

fields.name: academic_skills
fields.text:
# Academic Skills in the master
Academic Skills in the Master is a combination of knowledge (in your field), skills and attitude that is needed in your education and future career. Think of subjects such as:

* Communicative skills (writing reports, peer reviews, discussions and argumentation).
* Social and organisational skills (working together, functioning in a team and planning your own work and time).
* IT-skills (from working with known text editors, spreadsheet and presentation software to using specialized applications within your discipline).
* Literature research (finding relevant literature, analysing and using it).
* Peer reviewing and working professionally (reflect on your own knowledge, skills and attitude, self-knowledge, independence and steering your own development).


(source: [UvA studiegids](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/10867.html))

## Courses
In your master you require 6 EC in academic skills. Of these 6 EC, [Academic English](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/11181.html) is compulsory, the other 3 EC can be filled with [a few other courses](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/10867.html).


## Own Project Academic Skills:
However, there is also another option for the last 3 EC: [Own Project Academic Skills](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/10915.html). There seems to be a preference for outreach in these projects, however, combined with the comments in the academic skills quite a number of options should be valid. It is possible to choose something that you find more useful/have more fun in doing than one of the courses available under the Academic skills banner.

*[From the course page](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/10915.html)*

* Students are allowed to invent their own Academic Skills project and execute it, for 2-4EC. The project proposal is discussed and approved with the MSc director and with the coordinator for academic skills, and graded after the agreed-upon work and a report on it have been completed. Examples of such projects in the past have been: designing astronomy lessons or projects for elementary or secondary schools, supervising secondary-school student projects in astronomy, writing a popular article on one's MSc thesis work, helping the NOVA Information Centre with an outreach project. 

*[From the Academic Skills page:](http://studiegids.uva.nl/web/sgs/en/c/10867.html)*

Students can also show that they have acquired academic skills individually. These improvements may be achieved in activities such as:

* An outreach project.
* A teaching project at a secondary school.
* Supervising pupils of secondary education who visit the research institute for project work.
* Volunteer work at an observatory or science centre.
* Substantial contributions to the organization of a science conference.
* Editorial work for students’ magazines in your subject.
* Volunteer work at the faculty such as part of the visitation committee.
* Traineeships at companies.

Every activity where academic skills are involved such as communication, writing and editing, orientation on your future career, promotion of your subject for a broad audience, executive work related to your subject, development of teaching material, teaching can be taken into account. The workload of an activity must be about 3 EC (= 2 weeks of work). The conditions for an activity to be approved are:

* Before you start you must deliver a work plan.
* Get the approval from the master coordinator in advance.
* At the end deliver a description of your activities.
* Reflect on your work in writing.
* A final interview can be part of the review.

# Wireless

# Getting eduroam wireless to work

[ICT instructions for eduroam](http://student.uva.nl/eco/az/item/wireless-internet.html)

## How to connect? 

To establish a connection to the UvA wireless network you will first need to install the SecureW2 security software on your device (laptop, tablet or smartphone). 

## If you already have an Internet connection (e.g. mobile Internet) 

Go to [www.wifiportal.uva.nl](http://www.wifiportal.uva.nl). This page checks your operating system to ensure you download the right software (e.g. for Windows, Mac OS X or Android). Check to see if the right operating system is selected and click JoinNow. The SecureW2 software will now be downloaded. Install the software on your device.

## If you are at a UvA location 

Establish a connection with the UvAguests wireless network. Once your connection has been established, open your Internet browser and go to [www.wifiportal.uva.nl](http://www.wifiportal.uva.nl) (Internet Explorer will direct you to this page automatically). This page checks your operating system to ensure you download the right software (e.g. for Windows, Mac OS X or Android). Check to see if the right operating system is selected and click JoinNow. The SecureW2 software will now be downloaded. Install the software on your device.

## After installing the software 

Once you have installed the SecureW2 software you can start using wireless Internet at the UvA by selecting the ‘uva’ or ‘eduroam’ wireless networks and logging in with your UvAnetID.

# Wireless account for guests

If you have a guest (or more), it's easy to set up wireless access for them. Go to [https://guests.ic.uva.nl/](https://guests.ic.uva.nl/), log in with your UvAnetID, and create a single guest user account. 

It may be good to use your email address instead of theirs, so that the login details will be sent to someone who actually has internet access (the details will also be shown on the page itself, so the email is a backup). 

Take care of the time stamps and time zone settings (maximum allowed is 3 weeks before you need to create a new one), but otherwise, you should have a guest wireless account within 15 minutes or so.




# Old info about the wireless network that could be helpful

* [Linux & eduroam](http://staff.science.uva.nl/~kholshei/linux_guide/)
* [Ubuntu & eduroam](ubuntu_wireless_setup)
* [Mac & eduroam](mac_os_x-wireless-setup) or [Mac mobile devices](iPod-Wireless-Setup)
* [Windows & eduroam](http://student.uva.nl/eco/az/item/wireless-internet.html)
* [Wireless account for guests](guest-wireless)

 If you need some sort of certificate file for the wireless, then you'll need this one: [http://secure.globalsign.net/cacert/ct_root.der](http://secure.globalsign.net/cacert/ct_root.der)
